headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Rockwell Collins First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and management introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Rockwell Collins' Vice Pre
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Rockwell Collins First Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. 
For opening remarks and management introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Rockwell Collins' Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Ryan Miller. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sean, and good morning to all of you on the call. With me on the line this morning are Rockwell Collins' Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Kelly Ortberg; and Senior Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, Patrick Allen. Today
componenttext:
Thank you, Sean, and good morning to all of you on the call. With me on the line this morning are Rockwell Collins' Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Kelly Ortberg; and Senior Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, Patrick Allen. Today's call is being webcast, and you can view this webcast that will be presented today on the web site at webcast www.rockwellcollins.com under the Investor Relations tab. These slides include certain non-GAAP financial information and a reconciliation to the related GAAP measure. Please note, today's presentation and webcast will include certain projections and statements that are forward-looking. Actual results may differ materially from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties including those detailed on Slide 2 of this webcast presentation and, from time to time, in the company's Securities and Exchange Commission filings. These forward-looking statements are made as of today and the company assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements. 
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Kelly.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ryan, and good morning, everyone. If you recall on last quarter's earnings call, we said that we expected the first half of fiscal year '16 to be a slow start to the year followed by growth in the second half. We expected the first quarter to be t
componenttext:
Thanks, Ryan, and good morning, everyone. If you recall on last quarter's earnings call, we said that we expected the first half of fiscal year '16 to be a slow start to the year followed by growth in the second half. We expected the first quarter to be the weakest and in fact it was even a little weaker than we anticipated, most notably, in government systems. So let me take that head-on and summarize the performance and outlook of each of the businesses and I'll start with our Government Systems business. 
Due to program timing, we have expected our Government Systems business to be down mid-single digits in the first half followed by nice growth in the second half resulting in overall low single-digit growth for the year. In the first quarter, we did experience the anticipated headwinds that we outlined on last quarter's earnings call. However, we were also impacted by 2 issues that we did not anticipate. 1 was a supplier issue that impacted late quarter deliveries of some products and the other was a delay in some expected follow-on orders. All in the supplier issue and order timing delay caused about a 500 basis point impact to our Government Systems for the quarter. The good news is that we've already resolved the supplier issue and we have booked one of the delayed orders and I expect to recover both the order timing and product delivery catch up within the year. 
Now I know that it makes investors nervous when growth is back end loaded, so I'd like to provide some additional color on what we expect to drive that growth in our Government Systems' second half. Roughly 60% of the back half growth is either in backlog or annual follow-on business, where our customers make annual buys throughout the year. All this looks to be well funded, so I don't see much risk here. About 25% of the second half growth is in programs that we have won but are not yet awarded. The only risk is the timing of the contract action and we're tracking that very closely now are confident that we're closing in a timely manner for our year. And then the last 15% of the second half growth are programs that we have yet to go out and win. And that number is in line with our normal historical anticipated sales profile for this point in the year. So despite the challenging first quarter, I remain confident in our low single-digit growth for the full year in Government Systems. 
Now before I move from government systems, I do want to make a few comments about the budget outlook. First of all, the new budget is not good news for our Government business. If you recall, we've been forecasting our government business with sequestration as the budget baseline and as I'm sure you know, the agreement is an improvement from that baseline. I also believe that we're well positioned to at least get our fair share of the budget increases, given their priorities and the breadth of our portfolio. I would expect that we'll start seeing some of this improvement as early as next year. In fact, I wouldn't be surprised if we get a little tail wind on short cycle orders by the end of this year. So this is a strong boost to our plan to return government systems to sustained growth. 
Moving now to Commercial Systems. First quarter results were in line with our expectations. OEM sales were down, primarily driven by the impact of the previously announced Global Express rate reductions at Bombardier, but we did see nice growth in our Commercial Systems aftermarket. We delivered another quarter of strong operating performance headlined by 22.2% operating margins and our Commercial Systems team did a really great job of controlling their spending to manage the margin impact from the Global 5000, 6000 production cuts at Bombardier. 
Fiscal 2016 is an important year of program execution for our Commercial Systems and we completed a large number of milestones in the first quarter, including the certification of the C Series and ARJ-21 aircraft, first flight of the Mitsubishi Regional Jet, entry into service of the Challenger 650 at Bombardier, entry into service of the Fusion equipped King Airs at Cessna and entry into service of the legacy 450 at Embraer. All these programs are important in our long-term growth plan for our Commercial Systems business. 
Now finally, let me turn to Information Management Services where we delivered mid-single-digit topline sales growth for the quarter and some really strong operating margin performance, 130 basis point improvement over the year -- over the prior year. Our core Aviation business grew at 7% and continues to drive the incremental margin improvement that we expect from that business. In the year, most -- I'm sorry -- last year, most of our revenue synergies from the business aviation side of the business were leveraging synergies between the ARINCDirect services and Rockwell Collins' international flight operation service portfolios. And while we anticipate some additional opportunities in this part of the business, we're now starting to see synergies in other areas of the business. For example, we've secured a number of new agreements to provide Global Xpress connectivity services in the cabin, allowing us to address the broadband connectivity market that we have not previously served. We also signed launch customers for our ARINC MultiLink flight tracking service, which is compliant with the new European mandate that will help airlines keep track of their fleet. 
I know I probably sound like a broken record, but I continue to be extremely pleased with the acquisition of ARINC for both the financial perspective and how well the culture of the ARINC team and the Rockwell Collins' family. I think we continue to expect more good things to come from this business. 
So in summary for the quarter, I feel really good about achieving our full-year plan. We have good line of sight to the second half of growth and we successfully executed our restructuring plan in the first quarter, which will deliver benefits going forward. The permanent reinstatement of the Federal R&D Tax Credit and the 2015 government budget deal are both very positive catalyst for Rockwell Collins' future and I continue to believe, with strong execution on new programs, we have a very optimistic outlook for the long-term growth drivers of our company. 
So with that as an overview, let me turn it over to Patrick and have him walk through the financial details.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kelly, and good morning to everyone as well. I'd now like to walk you through today's presentation slides that summarize our results for the first quarter of fiscal 2016. I'll begin on Slide 3 where we highlight our total company first quarter sal
componenttext:
Thanks, Kelly, and good morning to everyone as well. I'd now like to walk you through today's presentation slides that summarize our results for the first quarter of fiscal 2016. I'll begin on Slide 3 where we highlight our total company first quarter sales, earnings per share, income from continuing operations and shares outstanding. Total company sales for the quarter decreased $57 million or 5% compared to the first quarter of last year, primarily due to lower government systems sales. Income from continuing operations decreased $36 million or 21% and earnings per share from continuing operations decreased $0.26 or 21% compared to the same period last year. 
Income from continuing operations includes a $28 million after-tax or $0.21 per share restructuring charge, primarily related to headcount actions across the company, which we are taking as a result of challenging market conditions, particularly in Business Aviation. In addition, the first quarter of both fiscal 2015 and 2016 includes our retroactive benefit from the Federal R&D Tax Credit of $0.16 and $0.18, respectively. 
As we turn to Slide 4, Commercial Systems achieved revenue of $562 million for the quarter, down 1% compared to the same period last year. Sales related to aircraft OEMs decreased $18 million or 5% to $313 million, primarily due to lower business jet aircraft OEM production rates, unfavorable airline selectable equipment mix and lower Airbus 330 production rates. All of that was partially offset by higher deliveries in support of the Airbus A350 and Embraer legacy business jet production ramps. Aftermarket sales increased $17 million or 8%, primarily due to higher head-up display retrofit sales in China, higher inorganic sales from the acquisition of Pacific Avionics and International Communications Group, and higher regulatory mandate sales. Commercial Systems operating earnings were basically flat compared to last year with operating margins improving 20 basis points from 22% to 22.2%. 
Operating earnings and margin benefited from lower company funded research and development expense, partially offset by negative mix as an increasing customer-funded development sales offset lower Business Aviation product sales as well as higher cost from the Pacific Avionics and ICG acquisitions and higher costs from further expansion in international emerging markets. 
Now moving on to Slide 5. You'll see that we reclassified Government Systems sales categories into Avionics and Communication and Navigation. These sales categories have been consoled from the previous categories to be consistent with an internal reorganization and are delineated based on the underlying product technologies. Now Government Systems overall revenue decreased by 11% to $451 million, driven by lower rotary wing hardware sales, the timing of deliveries for the E-6 program, the wind down of an international electronic warfare program, lower simulation and training sales and lower international targeting system sales. Government Systems' first quarter operating earnings decreased $20 million to $86 million, resulting in operating margin of 19.1% compared to 20.8% in the first quarter of last year. The decreased operating earnings and margin resulted from lower sales volume. 
Turning to Slide 6. Information Management Services sales increased 5% over the prior year as commercial and business aviation services sales increased 7%, while the non-aviation-related businesses were flat compared to last year. Information Management Services' first quarter operating earnings increased $3 million to $24 million, resulting in an operating margin of 15.4% compared to 14.1% in the first quarter of last year. The increase in operating earnings and margin was due to incremental earnings and higher sales volume. 
Now Slide 7 provides an update of R&D investment. Total spend decreased from $231 million in the first quarter of fiscal 2015 to $228 million in the first quarter of 2016. Company funded R&D decreased $17 million due to lower development expenditures for the Embraer Legacy 450 and Airbus A350 as well as lower business jet product line development costs. Customer-funded research and development expense increased $5 million due to higher development costs for international programs in Commercial Systems. And production engineering investment net increased due to higher cost incurred for certain military transport programs in government systems. 
Moving to Slide 8. We show the status of our capital structure as of the end of the first quarter compared to the end of last year. During the quarter, our debt-to-EBITDA ratio increased to 2.0 from 1.7 at year end. The increase was primarily due to an increase in commercial paper as the first quarter had typically light cash flows. I expect the level of debt to come down over the balance of the year as a larger portion of our cash flow is traditionally generated later in the year and we paid down a portion of that short-term debt. The updated status of the share repurchase program as of the end of the first quarter is detailed on Slide 9. During the first quarter, we repurchased 1 million shares at an average cost of $87.40. Our repurchase authority remaining at the end of the quarter was about $290 million. 
Now on to Slide 10 where we provide a summary of our fiscal year 2016 financial guidance, which has been updated as a result of the permanent reinstatement of the Federal R&D Tax Credit as well as an updated restructuring charge. Total sales in segment operating margins remain unchanged from the previous guidance. The earnings per share range has been increased by $0.25. The Federal R&D Tax Credit provided about a $0.35 benefit to our fiscal year 2016 earnings per share guidance and is partially offset by higher restructuring expense and higher incentive compensation expense. The cash flow from operations range has been increased by $50 million, primarily due to the benefit of that Federal R&D Tax Credit. 
Fiscal 2016 guidance for research and development investment and capital expenditures remains unchanged. Our effective tax rate for the fiscal year 2016 is now expected to be in the range of 22% to 23%, down from the previous guidance of about 28%, due again to the retroactive and perspective benefit from the Federal R&D Tax Credit. The second quarter of the year will have an effective tax rate of about 30%, which includes the benefit of that tax credit. And the third and fourth quarters will be similar to the second quarter, however, we expect some lumpiness to happen in the quarters as a benefit from certain tax planning strategies is expected to be realized. 
That completes my review of the financial results from projections. So Ryan, back to you to kick off the Q&A session.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of David Strauss from UBS Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of David Strauss from UBS Securities.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, maybe touch on business jets, business jet OE, how you're feeling about things. I think, since you gave us guidance last time came out with some pretty weak numbers, seems like all the indicators on the business jet side continue to weaken. Maybe t
componenttext: Kelly, maybe touch on business jets, business jet OE, how you're feeling about things. I think, since you gave us guidance last time came out with some pretty weak numbers, seems like all the indicators on the business jet side continue to weaken. Maybe talk about not only guidance for this year, but you think the ability of the OEMs to kind of hold at this lower production rates and not have to go down either lower from here.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. If you recall, we had put a little bit of discount in our forecast associated with anticipated further challenges to OEM production rates. What we normally have happened is, at this time of year, all the OEMs really gave us a trued up forecast
componenttext: Yes, David. If you recall, we had put a little bit of discount in our forecast associated with anticipated further challenges to OEM production rates. What we normally have happened is, at this time of year, all the OEMs really gave us a trued up forecast as to what they're going to do for the year and, in fact, we did see that production rate decline. Really, we saw declines from most of the OEMs and you've heard, as you pointed out, you've heard some weakness described in the market from those folks. In fact, we'd use of the reserves but I had allocated for that. Now they typically hold pretty well through the fiscal year, if there's another adjustment that usually comes around the summer for low work time off period. So we're hopeful that we're trued up for the year. And that's what we put that discount there. Unfortunately, is it kind of the opportunity if we needed that discount to reflect this. As far as the long-term outlook, it still remain soft, David. And we continue to be fairly conservative in our outlook for Business Aviation. Now these rate levels are pretty low. I think they can be sustained, but we do need to continue to watch that market going forward. I don't have a better crystal ball for what production rates are going to look like next year. We'll true that off when we provide our guidance for next year.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Safran from the Buckingham Research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a question on the aftermarket and about intertrade and the demand you're seeing from refurbished parts. There is some indications of increasing demand for refurbished parts. I want to know if you can comment on that, what you're seeing the
componenttext: I wanted to ask a question on the aftermarket and about intertrade and the demand you're seeing from refurbished parts. There is some indications of increasing demand for refurbished parts. I want to know if you can comment on that, what you're seeing there. Also, given that the inventory of aircraft cannabalized for refurbished parts is finite, just wondering if you're seeing improving demand, how long you might expect that to last?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so our intertrade business is seeing improved demand or increasing demand for used components and that's -- Richard, that's really not new. We saw that all through last year. We're expecting to be up double-digit in our intertrade business this year
componenttext: Well, so our intertrade business is seeing improved demand or increasing demand for used components and that's -- Richard, that's really not new. We saw that all through last year. We're expecting to be up double-digit in our intertrade business this year. And I think that's a trend that's here to stay. So I think you just got to look at where that used components, it's going to be a function of what aircraft are being retired in the pace of retirement and that's what's going to drive that market. I think it's becoming a best practice in the industry and as I've mentioned in the last call, we're seeing it now being used components recycling as being utilized in Asia Pac where we -- typically, they've always bought new spares in the past. So I think it's here to stay and that's why we've kind of factored our aftermarket to grow a little slower than what you're going to see the traffic grow, because I think that aftermarket is going to be impacted by the recycling of the used components. Now luckily, we have a used components business, unfortunately, it's not quite big enough to offset the impact that we'll see in our overall MRO. But I think that's here to stay, Richard.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ken Herbert from Canaccord Genuity.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ken Herbert from Canaccord Genuity.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, I just wondered if I could start off. There's been obviously a lot of speculations with the announcement yesterday on the 747 cut from Boeing just about the health of the original equipment commercial cycle. And I just wondered if I could get your
componenttext: Kelly, I just wondered if I could start off. There's been obviously a lot of speculations with the announcement yesterday on the 747 cut from Boeing just about the health of the original equipment commercial cycle. And I just wondered if I could get your thoughts on sort of if you see any incremental risk in the last month or so relative to some of your initial plans on either build rates on the 737, 787. Any particular incremental areas of risk you'd highlight beyond what's been publicly announced or any updated thoughts on sort of the OE outlook on the transport side here this year and into '17?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, really nothing new to the I'd highlight. I don't think the 747-8 rate change probably surprises any of us. Obviously, all eyes are on the basic 777 backlog and the ability of Boeing to sustain that. And we're still watching that just like you are. I'
componenttext: Ken, really nothing new to the I'd highlight. I don't think the 747-8 rate change probably surprises any of us. Obviously, all eyes are on the basic 777 backlog and the ability of Boeing to sustain that. And we're still watching that just like you are. I've got nothing to update you on that. One thing I've said is that Boeing would need to give us an updated rate forecast on the existing 777 here pretty soon to have any impact on our fiscal year '16. And the fact that they came out with rate changes on 747-8 and didn't do that on 777 tells me that there's still margin to their client to sustain the basic 777 raise, at least through the demand for our fiscal '16. So nothing new really to report on that, still very healthy backlog for us. And as you know, we've got new share gain opportunities coming into the market.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland from Barclays Capital.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on the aftermarket. When do you expect to see any material impact from A350 provisioning sales? Is that later this year kind of impact? Or does it take fiscal '17 to really see any material uptick there?
componenttext: Just a quick question on the aftermarket. When do you expect to see any material impact from A350 provisioning sales? Is that later this year kind of impact? Or does it take fiscal '17 to really see any material uptick there?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're probably not going to spike out, see material impact from A350 provisioning. We've already seen initial provisioning and you really didn't see that as a major spike like we saw on 787. It's a little bit of a function of the commodities that we prov
componenttext: You're probably not going to spike out, see material impact from A350 provisioning. We've already seen initial provisioning and you really didn't see that as a major spike like we saw on 787. It's a little bit of a function of the commodities that we provide on the 2 different airplanes. They're different as well as the fewer number of new airlines taking A350 as opposed to 87 when it came out, it had a lot of different airlines. I think, Carter, the next big provisioning spike for us is really 737MAX. And we'll start to see that maybe a little bit at the end of this year and, certainly, into next year, we'll see some of the provisioning input for that.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein from Wells Fargo.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to know if you can talk just more about the aftermarket just in general. How much of the 8% overall, the 16% business jet aftermarket was organic versus acquired? And then can you just talk a little bit about the parts, the retrofit, the upgrade
componenttext: Just want to know if you can talk just more about the aftermarket just in general. How much of the 8% overall, the 16% business jet aftermarket was organic versus acquired? And then can you just talk a little bit about the parts, the retrofit, the upgrades, the provisioning just kind of the different buckets, how we outperformed?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you kind of look overall, we are up 8% as we've disclosed here. Air transport was up low-single digit and that was really retrofits, some cabin wireless activity, mandates are down in the air transport. We're going to see that throughout the year that
componenttext: If you kind of look overall, we are up 8% as we've disclosed here. Air transport was up low-single digit and that was really retrofits, some cabin wireless activity, mandates are down in the air transport. We're going to see that throughout the year that the mandate revenue is down there. Interesting enough, mandates overall were up because mandates were very good for the quarter in Business Aviation. And finally, we saw a really nice quarter of avionics upgrades where they're putting fans updates to the bizjet avionics. I'm very helpful that, that will continue and actually provide us a little bit of opportunity for the full year. In terms of inorganic revenue, about $8 million in the aftermarket and almost all of it is in air transport, actually.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Sam, if I kind of gave you a little bit of an outlook, I think we can increase our growth rate throughout the year in air transport, you're going to see the Business Aviation numbers mute a little bit. We're not going to see quite as high growth rate.
componenttext: So Sam, if I kind of gave you a little bit of an outlook, I think we can increase our growth rate throughout the year in air transport, you're going to see the Business Aviation numbers mute a little bit. We're not going to see quite as high growth rate. But overall, we still feel good about that high single-digit growth in our aftermarket.

componenttext: Kelly, you mentioned on the government side about the potential posted impact of the FY '16 at DoD budget. I was wondering if you could comment on what you're seeing in the defense export market. So whether there's been any impact as yet from the decline in the oil price.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Non whatsoever. It's something we keep an eye on. But in fact all the priority funding, our Saudi effort team program, continues to be funded as expected. We've got some follow-on business, high-priority business in the Middle East and targeting and t
componenttext: No. Non whatsoever. It's something we keep an eye on. But in fact all the priority funding, our Saudi effort team program, continues to be funded as expected. We've got some follow-on business, high-priority business in the Middle East and targeting and those all of those programs seem to be well funded. So no, I'm not seeing any -- the oil issue seem to be playing through the commercial business much more than the defense business.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's been a couple of questions on a transport aftermarket. I just want a little bit more color there. It looks like, organically, it was down about 4.5% in the first quarter, and Kelly, you talked about kind of the new trends that are going on there.
componenttext: There's been a couple of questions on a transport aftermarket. I just want a little bit more color there. It looks like, organically, it was down about 4.5% in the first quarter, and Kelly, you talked about kind of the new trends that are going on there. So full-year basis, I think previously you're expecting kind of mid-single-digit growth. Is this long term now, more of kind of a very low single digits 2%, 3% type of market for you guys just because of the new trends there and maybe some Asia weakness, Asia changes. Can you give us a little more color?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the basic MRO component of the aftermarket is probably about right because of that recycling that I talked about. But then we have the discretionary side that tends to be a little more lumpy. We've got mandate driven revenue. We've got these
componenttext: Yes. I think the basic MRO component of the aftermarket is probably about right because of that recycling that I talked about. But then we have the discretionary side that tends to be a little more lumpy. We've got mandate driven revenue. We've got these retrofits of heads up displays and head down display systems on sub-5767. And then we have the provisioning things that we talked about earlier that tend to spike that. But I think if you strip the discretionary away and look at the fundamental MRO, I think you're probably about right.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any incremental headwinds at all from Asia, given some of the volatility over there?
componenttext: Okay. And any incremental headwinds at all from Asia, given some of the volatility over there?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have seen a little bit of incremental headwinds in our flight services business in IMS where we're doing international trip support. If you look at our growth rate, it was just a lower than what we've been expecting. And almost all of that softne
componenttext: Well, we have seen a little bit of incremental headwinds in our flight services business in IMS where we're doing international trip support. If you look at our growth rate, it was just a lower than what we've been expecting. And almost all of that softness is just international trips. In fact, our international trips for the quarter were down about 6%. We're gaining customers, but they're flying fewer international legs right now. And I think that China, Russia and Brazil are the areas I'd spike out that are causing that. Hopefully, that stabilizes here going forward.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could touch on the government side and I think you want to give quarterly guidance, but how quickly can you recover in 2Q back to that down mid single-digit trend you originally thought about. Are you at a point where you're kind of back
componenttext: I was hoping you could touch on the government side and I think you want to give quarterly guidance, but how quickly can you recover in 2Q back to that down mid single-digit trend you originally thought about. Are you at a point where you're kind of back on the recovery profile or is 2Q trends kind of look similar to 1Q?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me talk about that. First of all, it's unfortunate that -- and disappointing that we have the issues that got piled on a soft quarter. The product issue, if at any other quarter than the holiday quarter, I think we'd had it resolved and won't
componenttext: Yes. So let me talk about that. First of all, it's unfortunate that -- and disappointing that we have the issues that got piled on a soft quarter. The product issue, if at any other quarter than the holiday quarter, I think we'd had it resolved and won't even have to talk to you about it. So we've already got the issues resolved with the customers. We're making the delivery. So that will go pretty quickly. We booked one of the major orders that was a Pakistan C-130 that we're anticipated. So that will move forward. So I'm pretty confident that we'll be able to recover that in the fiscal year, maybe not all in the second quarter, but certainly by the end of the year. So we're still kind of forecasting down mid-single digits for the first half and then growth in the second half.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of the dime, Patrick, that you mentioned was being absorbed by higher incentive comp and extra restructuring. How much is extra restructuring of that and where is it going?
componenttext: Of the dime, Patrick, that you mentioned was being absorbed by higher incentive comp and extra restructuring. How much is extra restructuring of that and where is it going?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Think of it as about half and half and the increase is largely in the voluntary retirement program, which is spread across the businesses.
componenttext: Think of it as about half and half and the increase is largely in the voluntary retirement program, which is spread across the businesses.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to ARIC and just ask if you could give us a little more of a window into actually what's going on in the business, maybe separate the aviation from the non-aviation and talk about how you're going to get to that higher single-digit gro
componenttext: I wanted to go back to ARIC and just ask if you could give us a little more of a window into actually what's going on in the business, maybe separate the aviation from the non-aviation and talk about how you're going to get to that higher single-digit growth rate later in the year. And maybe also if you could comment on the relative profitability of the different businesses in there. Because it seems like the non-aviation's still the lower margin business.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is. And if you look, really, the economic engine, as I've mentioned, and the incremental margin comes from the growth in the core aviation business. The non-aviation business, we've called about lumpy in the past where we tended to have project or
componenttext: Yes, it is. And if you look, really, the economic engine, as I've mentioned, and the incremental margin comes from the growth in the core aviation business. The non-aviation business, we've called about lumpy in the past where we tended to have project oriented programs. I'll admit it's been consistently lumpy down. So if you look at the performance of that business has been pretty flat. And it was flat this quarter. I am expecting growth in the non-aviation component of the business. So we'll see an improved overall growth rate and we put some strategies in place to address the growth in that business. Now I think this is going to be an important year to see whether those strategies are going to play out. But we are achieving our overall EBITDA growth expectations because of the fact that we are achieving the core aviation growth that we expect and that we are achieving or a little bit exceeding the incremental margin performance that's coming with that growth. So again, I feel pretty good about it. The only headwind that I see that maybe we didn't anticipate was this international trip support. I think that's temporary for us and we'll be back with the growth in international trips, but we're just going to have to work through that economic issues here that we've got in those regions.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So would you say that Q1 was below plan?
componenttext: So would you say that Q1 was below plan?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Q1 was maybe a point below what I was expecting.
componenttext: Yes. Q1 was maybe a point below what I was expecting.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: But you still feel pretty good about your original guide?
componenttext: But you still feel pretty good about your original guide?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do.
componenttext: Yes, I do.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to be clear, was below plan was in the non-aviation business and really the timing of some deliveries there.
componenttext: And just to be clear, was below plan was in the non-aviation business and really the timing of some deliveries there.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I guess the question is can the aviation to make up for that or can the non-aviation make up for that?
componenttext: But I guess the question is can the aviation to make up for that or can the non-aviation make up for that?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've been able to make up by driving the growth in the aviation. We have got to get this non-aviation business off this flat forecast and that's the strategy. My team knows that very well. I think we've got some plans to do that. So if we can just get so
componenttext: We've been able to make up by driving the growth in the aviation. We have got to get this non-aviation business off this flat forecast and that's the strategy. My team knows that very well. I think we've got some plans to do that. So if we can just get some average growth off the non-aviation and continue with that really strong growth of the aviation business, I feel really good about achieving our long-term outlooks.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from the line of Kyle of Cowen & Company.
componenttext: You're next question comes from the line of Kyle of Cowen & Company.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you've raised your EPS guidance by $0.25. I think the R&D tax credit is plus 30 and you mentioned on the negative side the restructuring and incentive comp. I mean, my understanding was the restructuring savings in the last 9 months would at least equa
componenttext: So you've raised your EPS guidance by $0.25. I think the R&D tax credit is plus 30 and you mentioned on the negative side the restructuring and incentive comp. I mean, my understanding was the restructuring savings in the last 9 months would at least equal the first quarter's charge and then, I guess, I don't understand why the incentive comp is up when you missed your plan in the first quarter. So if you could explain those issues.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say both the restructuring charge and the savings are up from our original estimate. I'd say the charge is up little bit more because we've got -- have some need to backfill some of the people put up a voluntary early retirement program. So
componenttext: Sure. I would say both the restructuring charge and the savings are up from our original estimate. I'd say the charge is up little bit more because we've got -- have some need to backfill some of the people put up a voluntary early retirement program. So it's really disparity between the size of the charge and the size of the savings that's generating -- that was roughly a nickel of headwind to the R&D tax credit. And the impact on incentive compensation, if you remember, last time we had a big catch up in R&D. We had an EPS as a goal, and incentive compensation. We took that out but we still have a goal associated with cash flow and the R&D tax credit generated incremental cash flow, which is generating higher incentive compensation because we've raised our cash flow goal by $50 million. So that's the other component of the, I'll say roughly a dime that's offsetting the $0.35 benefit in R&D tax credit.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro from Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro from Shapiro Research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I look at the commercial margin x R&D since its clearly benefited, it was dropped 170 basis points since 30.1% to 28.4%. Now you mentioned that you had a little impact with higher low-margin, customer-funded, higher cost from Pacific Avionics. So my qu
componenttext: If I look at the commercial margin x R&D since its clearly benefited, it was dropped 170 basis points since 30.1% to 28.4%. Now you mentioned that you had a little impact with higher low-margin, customer-funded, higher cost from Pacific Avionics. So my question is, will R&D stay at this lower level throughout the year or are there other some of those other issues I just mentioned, one-time items? Or what's going on to effectively cause 170 basis point drop in the underlying margin?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, I think your math is spot on and I think it you've identified the cause of why the margin has been impacting the first quarter. Now what's going to happen going forward is we're going to see, I'll say a steady shift between a company funded R&D go
componenttext: George, I think your math is spot on and I think it you've identified the cause of why the margin has been impacting the first quarter. Now what's going to happen going forward is we're going to see, I'll say a steady shift between a company funded R&D going up and our deferred engineering investment coming down over the course of the quarter -- quarters. Now that's going to be offset by restructuring savings, which as I mentioned earlier in the call, we didn't get much of any in the first quarter. So we'll be benefiting from the restructuring savings, plus we should be getting higher volume and with higher volume, getting the incremental flow on that. So I'm confident that we'll continue to generate good margins on the commercial side of the business, but the dynamics will be as I described.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to the government systems growth rate in the quarter. With the supplier quality issue, any incremental detail you can provide on exactly what that was or where it was? And then on the order timing, which sounds like a separate issue, s
componenttext: I wanted to go back to the government systems growth rate in the quarter. With the supplier quality issue, any incremental detail you can provide on exactly what that was or where it was? And then on the order timing, which sounds like a separate issue, somebody else in the fence has brought up the holidays, I guess I'm just wondering there was a system wide abnormal end of year issue? And can you quantify what the growth rate would have been in the business without these sort of transitory items?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It was about 5 points of impact to our Government Systems growth rate. So we were down 11, we would have been down 6 without them. The supplier issue was a nonconforming material issue on a connector that we used in our R-210 radios. In fact, we didn
componenttext: Yes. It was about 5 points of impact to our Government Systems growth rate. So we were down 11, we would have been down 6 without them. The supplier issue was a nonconforming material issue on a connector that we used in our R-210 radios. In fact, we didn't have to rework, we just needed to go through the quality paperwork and get a waiver in place. Unfortunately, that was at the end of the year and with the holidays, we couldn't get that waiver approved. So we've got that we were now approved. The products are shipping. So it really was just a blip. You should didn't think of that as kind of systemic issue. In terms of the order timing, the one that I've highlighted, the Pakistan C-130, we had expected quite early in the fiscal quarter. We actually got that here early this calendar year, but it delayed. And that's in FMS order. I don't think that was holiday related, Noah. I think that was just the normal challenge we have in trying to predict how fast things go through that cycle. I don't have anything else to highlight in government systems that was abnormal around the holiday.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And your short cycle defense comment, was that a change -- has that started to firm and then has maybe turned a little bit? Or is there no change in how you're seeing that progressing?
componenttext: Okay. And your short cycle defense comment, was that a change -- has that started to firm and then has maybe turned a little bit? Or is there no change in how you're seeing that progressing?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no change. Short cycle things like radios, munitions are the types of things would expect to see not in our re-programs would be another example. The things that we'll see out of the benefit of this budget update. And so there's no change in outlo
componenttext: No, no, no change. Short cycle things like radios, munitions are the types of things would expect to see not in our re-programs would be another example. The things that we'll see out of the benefit of this budget update. And so there's no change in outlook there.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Ciarmoli from KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Ciarmoli from KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe, Kelly, just to stay on the Government System. Specifically, I think you called out 15% of the back half that you need to go out, get and win. Can you give us some color. Is there a lot of FMS sales in\ there? And maybe also in FMS topic, can you to
componenttext: Maybe, Kelly, just to stay on the Government System. Specifically, I think you called out 15% of the back half that you need to go out, get and win. Can you give us some color. Is there a lot of FMS sales in\ there? And maybe also in FMS topic, can you touch on any risks related to the KC-390 program, given the kind of current state of the economy in Brazil?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me walk through each of those categories that I went through. For those of you who are program specific in government, you'll understand what programs are driving that. So I talked about 60% being firm and follow-on. If you look at the firm co
componenttext: Yes. So let me walk through each of those categories that I went through. For those of you who are program specific in government, you'll understand what programs are driving that. So I talked about 60% being firm and follow-on. If you look at the firm contracts, KC-390, KC-46, some rotary wing at AgustaWestland and Sikorsky, Saudi F-15 are all firm programs that have first half, second half growth. I'm confident that the KC-390 first half, second half growth will be achieved in spite of the economic situation. We're funded by Embraer. I don't mean they're necessarily funded by their customer, but they are going forward with that. I do think we'll probably see some future delays on the KC-390 program, but at this point, nothing in this fiscal year. Then in that, I also talk about follow-on in that 60%. And these are annual buys, things like the R-210, data links, our KC 135 Block 45 program, where the customer buys the annual work on a yearly basis. They're all funded, they're in the plan and I don't see, really, any risk there. The 15% that I talked about is really -- there's no real large program drivers. Some of them are international. These are things we'd either bid on or we're waiting a decision. And we also have quite a bit of just short cycle stuff where we get an order and sell it out as finished goods. And so we just track that kind of as a lot a little orders. We track that relative to how do we look firm this year versus historical. And we look pretty good with improving budget environment, that maybe actually opportunity for us. But I don't see anything that's out of the normal, nor do I see any major one program driver in that 15%.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gursky from Citi Investment Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gursky from Citi Investment Research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to stay with Government Systems. One last question here. You mentioned in your prepared remarks that you were expecting some level of annual renewals that kind of come through, but one of the things that we've heard from others is that the ann
componenttext: I just want to stay with Government Systems. One last question here. You mentioned in your prepared remarks that you were expecting some level of annual renewals that kind of come through, but one of the things that we've heard from others is that the annual renewals are beginning to get de-scoped in size. So the government buys 101 year and buys only 96 or 95 the following year. Can you just give us an extent of what you're seeing on your annual renewals and whether there's been any de-scope occurring for you guys?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say across-the-board de-scope. I think it depends on what. We do see some de-scope but we also see some increase in school. Our orders are higher than what we expected. We always look at the quantities on the KC 135, Block 45. But that's more g
componenttext: I wouldn't say across-the-board de-scope. I think it depends on what. We do see some de-scope but we also see some increase in school. Our orders are higher than what we expected. We always look at the quantities on the KC 135, Block 45. But that's more given by the pace at which the government can take the kits and get the aircraft modified. So we're always dealing with that, but nothing systemic or nothing that I would expect would be across-the-board and cause us any challenges. Radio quantities, mix quantities, tactical data links, all look good going forward. So nothing that I would be able to say, we see that trend.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a clarification question, if I can. On the IMS comment around international flight operations being under a little bit of pressure, can you let us know whether that was for commercial flights or bizjet flights or just kind of what the mix o
componenttext: Okay. And just a clarification question, if I can. On the IMS comment around international flight operations being under a little bit of pressure, can you let us know whether that was for commercial flights or bizjet flights or just kind of what the mix of that weakness is.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry. That's all Business Aviation. This is where we do trips, international trip support. So when a business aircraft makes an international trip, we provide service to them for that trip. And that's where we're seeing the weakness. It has nothing t
componenttext: I'm sorry. That's all Business Aviation. This is where we do trips, international trip support. So when a business aircraft makes an international trip, we provide service to them for that trip. And that's where we're seeing the weakness. It has nothing to do with air transport.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of of Howard Rubel from Jefferies and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of of Howard Rubel from Jefferies and Company.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Want to talk about implementation for a moment. You've got a lot of things that are going on this year, Kelly. And maybe you could address a couple of things. How are you doing in terms of implementing this restructuring program? I mean, you did make a ch
componenttext: Want to talk about implementation for a moment. You've got a lot of things that are going on this year, Kelly. And maybe you could address a couple of things. How are you doing in terms of implementing this restructuring program? I mean, you did make a change to the government business unit. The 737MAX is at a critical point before first light and you have to balance certain requirements and production rates. And then you got C Series and then just to finish on that is the change in the global and whether in fact you feel like you've understand the depth and the magnitude of that challenge.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, okay. A lot in that question. So first of all, I think the restructuring has gone very well. It's mainly a headcount reduction for us and it has all went out in the first quarter. So I'm very pleased with where we are. We do have some consolidation
componenttext: Well, okay. A lot in that question. So first of all, I think the restructuring has gone very well. It's mainly a headcount reduction for us and it has all went out in the first quarter. So I'm very pleased with where we are. We do have some consolidation and restructuring of our business to run more efficiently with fewer heads. And that's what drove, for example, the change that we made in our government systems portfolio. Our development programs are going very well. We're in great shape on MAX. I'm very excited about support and getting that aircraft in the first light and everything looks really good. So development programs are tracking quite well. I mentioned the C Series certification, now our teams are focused with supporting Bombardier to get to entry into service here middle of the year. As far as Business Aviation and the globals, we saw global impact. As I've mentioned, this quarter, that impact actually increases a little bit throughout the year. That was an area that we saw some additional truing up from Bombardier here as we went into the fiscal year. So yes, I think that we're going to just be challenged with that production rate, but I think we got it well sized now for the year.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of David Strauss from UBS Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of David Strauss from UBS Securities.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, you had mentioned the upside from the fiscal '16 budget. I wanted to see if you would care to speculate what that could mean or government systems growth looking out, '17, '18, 19. I think you previously said getting back to 2%, 3% kind of growth r
componenttext: Kelly, you had mentioned the upside from the fiscal '16 budget. I wanted to see if you would care to speculate what that could mean or government systems growth looking out, '17, '18, 19. I think you previously said getting back to 2%, 3% kind of growth rate. Could you maybe talk about the kind of upside we can see from the '16 budget out on those years?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, so the team's still kind of going through the actual program pads and how that all is going to flow. But I would hope that we'll see a point or 2 of higher growth than we had previously had anticipated, because that's what we're seeing out of t
componenttext: Yes. Well, so the team's still kind of going through the actual program pads and how that all is going to flow. But I would hope that we'll see a point or 2 of higher growth than we had previously had anticipated, because that's what we're seeing out of this budget environment. And again, I think we're pretty well positioned to at least get our fair share. So it's long term. I think it certainly firms up our ability to get this business back to low to mid-single-digit growth.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein of Wells Fargo.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Patrick, can you just talk a little bit about the preproduction engineering? For the $40 million increase, I guess, in the first quarter, you talked about $100 million for the year. I guess, are you still seeing that kind of an increase? And does that mea
componenttext: Patrick, can you just talk a little bit about the preproduction engineering? For the $40 million increase, I guess, in the first quarter, you talked about $100 million for the year. I guess, are you still seeing that kind of an increase? And does that mean it increases more earlier in the year and then it starts to actually reverse? Or is it just ...

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say yes. What we're going to see is over the course of the year, the amount that goes into the deferral is going to reduce over time. And actually, I think I mentioned it with George's question, you're going to see company-funded tick up little bi
componenttext: I would say yes. What we're going to see is over the course of the year, the amount that goes into the deferral is going to reduce over time. And actually, I think I mentioned it with George's question, you're going to see company-funded tick up little bit, company-funded the couple that over the course of the quarter. So you will see a little bit of a makeshift over the course of the year. And we still -- and we're on plan with respect to deferred. So I still feel very comfortable with that $100 million net increase.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of of Seth Seifman from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of of Seth Seifman from JPMorgan.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just if you could go back to the commercial aftermarket and you could talk maybe a little bit more about intertrade and you've talked for a while about the structural factor driving growth there. But just from a cyclical standpoint with low oil prices, a
componenttext: Just if you could go back to the commercial aftermarket and you could talk maybe a little bit more about intertrade and you've talked for a while about the structural factor driving growth there. But just from a cyclical standpoint with low oil prices, a lot of the data that we all have seen shows retirements were down last year and in terms of the in an environment maybe where not as many aircraft are being retired and maybe all the aircraft are flying little bit more. How does that cyclical dynamic affect intertrade and play out against the structural dynamical of more airlines looking to harvest used parts?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I can't -- I don't think I can point to exactly how much that dynamic would change our intertrade business. It's all the focus of that business is all around making sure you have the right demand for the right asset. You go buy the right asset that
componenttext: Well, I can't -- I don't think I can point to exactly how much that dynamic would change our intertrade business. It's all the focus of that business is all around making sure you have the right demand for the right asset. You go buy the right asset that you can turn. And so it really gets down to your program by program aircraft type by aircraft type specific dynamics that that team works. In the end, whether they slow the retirement rate, that will mean that there's probably fewer spares out there, but it also mean there are probably larger demand for those spares, those used spares. So the trick will be our ability to get to those used parts and the market to continue to grow. And I feel pretty confident that within the business that we're forecasting, we should be able to grow that, again, double-digit here for the year.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro from Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro from Shapiro Research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to pursue a little bit more. The business jet aftermarket is up 17%, you were saying that the inorganic was all air transport. So what do you look for business jet aftermarket going forward? I mean, last year, I guess, it's a pretty easy comp,
componenttext: Just wanted to pursue a little bit more. The business jet aftermarket is up 17%, you were saying that the inorganic was all air transport. So what do you look for business jet aftermarket going forward? I mean, last year, I guess, it's a pretty easy comp, but still it's a pretty healthy increase.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, remember, we've guided that business jet aftermarket will be fairly muted kind of like what we saw last year. I'm sleek, 17% is a gangbuster start to -- I think we saw 2% last year in growth. I don't, as i mentioned, I don't think. Continue at that
componenttext: Well, remember, we've guided that business jet aftermarket will be fairly muted kind of like what we saw last year. I'm sleek, 17% is a gangbuster start to -- I think we saw 2% last year in growth. I don't, as i mentioned, I don't think. Continue at that 17% rate because some the mandate activities will come down in Business Aviation. But I'm hopeful that if we continue to see like we've seen this quarter with good sales of avionics mod, that we'll be able to create some opportunity to our forecast there.

componenttext: Well, the market demand for our services for our products and for the aircraft continues to be very strong. But I'm not seeing any softness in their demand for aircraft or the number of flights they're doing in the air transport market. The aftermarket remains very robust. They're continuing to find HUD retrofits to meet their mandated service. So yes, the overall economy is slowing down, but I think still a very robust market for air transport.
