headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Rockwell Collins Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and management introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Rockwell Collins Vice Presi
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Rockwell Collins Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and management introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Rockwell Collins Vice President of Investor Relations, Ryan Miller. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning to all of you on the call. With me on the line this morning are Rockwell Collins Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Kelly Ortberg; and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Patrick Allen.Toda
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning to all of you on the call. With me on the line this morning are Rockwell Collins Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Kelly Ortberg; and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Patrick Allen.
Today's call is being webcast, and you can view the slides that we'll be presenting today on our website at www.rockwellcollins.com under the Investor Relations tab. These slides include certain non-GAAP financial information and a reconciliation to the related GAAP measure.
Please note, today's presentation and webcast will include certain projections and statements that are forward looking. Actual results may differ materially from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including those detailed on Slide 2 of this webcast presentation and from time to time in the company's Securities and Exchange Commission filings.  These forward-looking statements are made as of today and the company assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements.
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Kelly.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well. Thanks, Ryan, and good morning, everyone. With 2 quarters down, our fiscal year 2016 is progressing directionally as we expected. As we indicated in October and again in our last quarterly call, this is definitely a first half, second half story. An
componenttext:
Well. Thanks, Ryan, and good morning, everyone. With 2 quarters down, our fiscal year 2016 is progressing directionally as we expected. As we indicated in October and again in our last quarterly call, this is definitely a first half, second half story. And because we saw it coming, we've been very transparent about the Business Aviation production rates, as well as the Government Systems program timing and the impact on our top line sales profile for the year. 
We also, as you know, initiated a restructuring program to help sustain our bottom line performance. This restructuring was essentially complete in the first quarter, and I'm pleased to report that it's now delivering the savings that we expected. 
Now the largest shift in growth from the first half to the second half of the year is in our Government Systems business. So let me start here and give you an update on the metrics I outlined last quarter relative to that growth. 
In the last call, I said that about 60% of the back half growth was already in backlog or coming from annual buys of follow-on business. This category has now grown from 60% last quarter to 77% at the end of the second quarter. Again, this is all funded activities, so I don't see much risk here, and I'm pleased that we're making the progress in firming this up. 
Now the second category of growth is in programs that we have won, but have yet to be awarded. And this has decreased from 25% last quarter to 17% this quarter. The only risk in this area is moving these programs through the contracting action in the firm backlog. And at this point, I don't see anything that would keep us from firming up the 17%. And then the third category, which is the balance of the second half growth, is coming from programs that we have yet to go out and win. This category has decreased from 15% last quarter to now making up only 6% of our planned growth. As I look at all these metrics, we're right in line with our historical anticipated sales for this time of the year. So despite the challenging first half, we have good line of sight to the second half growth for government systems. And as a reminder, the fourth quarter is always the biggest in terms of sales and margins, and I do expect our growth rate to be the highest in the fourth quarter as well.
Now turning to Commercial Systems. The first half went about as expected, but the aftermarket components are a little different from what we originally anticipated. The business aviation has performed better-than-expected and the air transport aftermarket has been softer. As this turned out, the 2 have essential offset each other for the first half of the year, so our overall aftermarket performance remains on track. 
The strength in the Business Aviation aftermarket has been driven by mandates, which we expected, but also by stronger-than-expected cockpit retrofits. We introduced some new avionics aftermarket products late last year and they're selling quite well. The weaker air transport aftermarket is being driven by the impacts of recycling and we're also dealing with the impacts of more aggregators in the service market. I believe these are indicative of structural changes in how the airlines are managing their MRO needs, and we should no longer be expecting MRO to grow at traffic rate at least for the foreseeable future. 
Now air transport OEM rates are progressing as planned with production ramping for the 787, the A350 and the Airbus narrowbodies. These increases are partially offset by rate reductions in the A330. Now business jet OEM rates remain consistent with last quarter. And if you recall, I said in the last call, that the summer shutdown period is when we would likely see business jet reductions if there are going to be any more than happened this year. So that remains a watch area for us for the next quarter. 
Finally, let me turn to our Information Management Services business. This past quarter, we delivered 5% sales growth and really strong operating performance with margins improving by 370 basis points. Our core aviation business grew 8% for the quarter, driving the profitability for that business. 
While this is great performance, our top line to date is a bit lower than I expected. We are seeing weaker demand for Business Aviation international trips support, which has been hit pretty hard in Russia, China and in oil-producing countries. Without a pick-up here, we'll probably see our IMS business grow a bit slower for the full year than originally expected. We are expecting, though, to see growth in the second half from the non-aviation portion of the business. And I do want to point out that the better-than-expected profitability should more than offset any top line weakness in our IMS portfolio for the year. 
So having walked through the 3 business segments, let me now turn to our longer-term outlook. We achieved several very important milestones on programs that drive our long-term growth. These include the first flight of the Boeing 737 MAX with our new standard equipment all delivered on time and working very well. The first refueling flight was performed on the KC-46 tanker invalidating both our Avionics and the refueling mission package, which is a first using 3D image technology. And we're also selected as one of the suppliers on the U.S. Army's Manpack radio program, which is a key step towards bringing this large growth opportunity to reality.
Also in March, we are recognized by the Sphere Institute as one of 2016's most ethical companies, and this is the seventh year in a row receiving this award. So these achievements all demonstrate how we're striving to be the most trusted source of aviation and high integrity solutions in the world, and it's really some good reasons to be optimistic about the future of our company.
Now before I turn it over to Patrick, I do want to address an administrative item.  For years, we've issued our next fiscal year financial guidance in September. And I received feedback from many of you that it would make a lot more sense for us to issue the guidance when we announced our fourth quarter results, which typically happens at the end of October. So this is exactly what we plan to do for this coming year. Hopefully, this will make things more efficient for the investment community, as well as for Rockwell Collins, and it allow us to better align with the OEMs on production rates and we'll be able to discuss year-over-year financial guide because our full year results for fiscal '16 will be completed that time.
So with that out of the way, let me turn the call over to Patrick to walk us through the quarterly details.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kelly, and good morning to everyone as well. I'd now like to walk you through today's presentation slides that summarize our results for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. I'd like to begin on Slide 3, where we have our total company second quarte
componenttext:
Thanks, Kelly, and good morning to everyone as well. I'd now like to walk you through today's presentation slides that summarize our results for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. I'd like to begin on Slide 3, where we have our total company second quarter sales, earnings per share, income from continuing operations and shares outstanding. 
Total company sales for the quarter decreased $30 million or 2% compared to the second quarter last year, primarily due to lower Government Systems sales. Income from continuing operations increased $9 million or 6% and earnings per share from continuing operations increased $0.08 or 7% compared to the same period last year. The increase in income from continuing operations and earnings per share from continuing operations was primarily due to lower income tax expense due to permitted extension of federal research and development tax credit. 
As we turn to Slide 4, Commercial Systems achieved revenue of $611 million in the quarter, down 1% compared to the same period last year. Sales related to aircraft OEMs decreased $17 million or 5% to $353 million, primarily due to lower business aircraft OEM production rates, unfavorable airline sensible equipment mix and lower Airbus A330 production rates, all partially offset by higher customer funded development program sales, higher deliveries in support of the Airbus A350 and Boeing 787 production rate ramps, and higher Bombardier C-Series sales and support of the century to service later this year.
Aftermarket sales increased $14 million or 6%, primarily due to higher business jet avionics retrofit mandate sales and higher inorganic sales from the acquisition of the International Communications Group. Commercial Systems operating earnings decreased $7 million with operating margins declining 80 basis points from 22.9% to 22.1%. Operating earnings and margins decreased in the prior year primarily due to sales mix, as lower margin customer funded the boatman sales increased and higher-margin business jet OEM sales decreased. In addition, SG&A cost increased from higher costs associated with recent acquisitions. These were partially offset by a lower company funded research and development expense and cost savings initiatives from previously announced restructuring plans.
Moving on to Slide 5. Government Systems overall revenue decreased by 5% to $538 million, driven by lower rotary wing hardware sales, lower sales from simulation and training programs, the wind down of an international electronic warfare program and lower international targeting system deliveries. 
Government Systems second quarter operating earnings decreased $6 million to $108 million, resulting in an operating margin that was flat with the second quarter of the prior year at 20.1%. The decreased operating earnings resulted from the lower sales volume, partially offset by lower company funded research and development expense and cost-saving initiatives from previously announced restructuring plans.
Turning to Slide 6. Information Management Services sales increased 5% over the prior year, as commercial and Business Aviation services sales increased 8% while the non-aviation-related businesses were slightly down compared to last year. Information Management Services second quarter operating earnings increased $7 million and $29 million, resulting in an operating margin of 17.9% compared to 14.2% in the second quarter last year. The increase in operating earnings and margin was due to the incremental earnings and the higher sales volume, as well as a favorable resolution of some certain prior year claims associated with international business jet support services.
Looking next to Slide 7. We show year-to-date results for revenue, income from continuing operations, earnings per share and operating cash flow. Through the second quarter, we generated $45 million of operating cash flow compared to $132 million last year. The decrease in cash generation resulted from the lower pretax earnings and net unfavorable changes to working capital, which were primarily due to the timing of sales related advanced payments for customers. These items are partially offset by lower tax payments. 
Slide 8 provides an update of our total R&D investment. Total spend decreased from $489 million in the first 6 months of fiscal 2015 to $470 million in the first 6 months, I'm sorry, $489 million in the first 6 months of fiscal 2015 to $470 million in the first 6 months of FY '16. Company funded R&D decreased $43 million due to lower business jet development cost in Commercial Systems and lower Software Defined Radio development cost in Government Systems. Customer funded research and development expense increased $15 million due to higher development cost for regional jet development programs in Commercial Systems, partially offset by the wind down of international electronic warfare program in government systems. Preproduction engineering investment net increased to the higher costs incurred for military program in Government Systems.
Moving to Slide 9, we show the status of our cattle structure as of the end of the second quarter compared to the end of last year. During the first 6 months of FY '16, our debt-to-EBITDA ratio increased to 2.1 from 1.7 at year-end. The increase was primarily due to an increase in commercial paper as the first half of the year typically late cash flows. I expect this level of debt to come down over the balance of the year as a larger portion of our cash flow is traditionally generated later in the year and we pay down a portion of that short-term debt.
The updated status of the share repurchase program as of the end of the second quarter is detailed on Slide 10. During the second quarter, we repurchased 1.2 million shares at an average cost of $85.03. Our repurchase authority remaining at the end of the quarter was $192 million. 
Now to Slide 11, where we provide a summary of our fiscal year 2016 financial guidance, which remains unchanged from the guidance we want last quarter. We do now have some clarity on when we expect to benefit from the tax planning strategies that we initially guided would benefit the second half of fiscal '16. These tax funding strategies, which entail utilizing capital less carryforwards from prior years, is now expected to benefit our third fiscal quarter. Our tax rate for the third quarter will likely be in the midteens and the tax rate for the fourth quarter will likely be in the neighborhood of about 30%. We still expect the full year tax rate to be between 22% and 23%. 
I also wanted to talk about the trajectory of our operating margins over the last half of the year, and we're expecting operating margins be about flat sequentially from the second quarter to the third quarter. We do expect to the overall business will return to growth in the third quarter and net growth will drive incremental earnings. But we will also be shifting our engineering expense from deferred engineering to company funded engineering resulting in a fairly flat sequential total operating margins. 
As we look to the fourth quarter, you should expect to see more incremental margin growth due to the higher growth rate in sales that Kelly talked about a little earlier. 
That completes my review of the financial results and projections. So Ryan, back to you to kick off the Q&A session.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Kelly, you talked a little bit about bizjet aftermarket and some of the positives and also some of the concerns or change in dynamics and commercial. Specifically with bizjets, can you talk about whether it was categories and what kind of visibility you might have? And then also the same for the commercial market.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look at those 2, the commercial and bizjet aftermarket, I recognize it's kind of counterintuitive to the health of those underlying markets. But in Business Aviation, we continue to see very strong mandate growth this quarter, which we did exp
componenttext: Yes, if you look at those 2, the commercial and bizjet aftermarket, I recognize it's kind of counterintuitive to the health of those underlying markets. But in Business Aviation, we continue to see very strong mandate growth this quarter, which we did expect, as I said in the opening remarks. But we also introduced some fans upgrades, avionics upgrades into the market. And that -- again, that is selling very well. And I'm hopeful that, that will continue to sell and maybe give us some upside opportunity here in the balance of the year. In air transport, it's kind of the opposite story. We had mandate headwinds in air transport. Last year, we had a big engine sales, which didn't repeat. So we had a little bit of a comparable issue on that. If I strip all of the one-time activities, as well as our Intertrade use business sales out of air transport, just look at the fundamental MRO, we've been roughly flat the first 2 quarters in fundamental MRO. And I think that's about what we're going to see. They're flat to very low single-digit growth in that underlying MRO business as we deal with the new recycling phenomenon that's here to stay.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one follow-up, a little bit different. You talked about LRS-B and you had some other military win. Is there change in focus? And can you add anything with respect to the LRS-B opportunity?
componenttext: And then just one follow-up, a little bit different. You talked about LRS-B and you had some other military win. Is there change in focus? And can you add anything with respect to the LRS-B opportunity?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, no, I can't add anything on that other than we're pleased to be on the Northrop Grumman team. That's about all I can say there. I wouldn't say, Howard, it's a change in our focus. I just think it's a change in the opportunities. The market dynamics
componenttext: Well, no, I can't add anything on that other than we're pleased to be on the Northrop Grumman team. That's about all I can say there. I wouldn't say, Howard, it's a change in our focus. I just think it's a change in the opportunities. The market dynamics are getting better. We're certainly seeing lift in things like Jay dam production rates associated with what's going on in the world. We are still struggling with the timing of getting things through the contracting action. That didn't improve. And as you look at our government business for the first half of the year, we guided at down mid single-digit. We ended up at 8% down. So we are a little behind where we wanted to be, and it's mostly getting some of these selected programs through the contracting action a few for military sales specific programs. But we've got good visibility to that. I'm pretty confident we'll be able to get that done by the end of the fiscal year.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I was wondering if you can comment a bit on the business jet OEM -- business regional jet OEM end market. And the decline there you saw were, I guess, inclusive to some offsets from growth in the CSeries. So as you look at those, you kind of bifurcate
componenttext: So I was wondering if you can comment a bit on the business jet OEM -- business regional jet OEM end market. And the decline there you saw were, I guess, inclusive to some offsets from growth in the CSeries. So as you look at those, you kind of bifurcate them. Could you talk about, is the business regional? I know you've gone through your contingency as it relates to business jets. But are you now below that contingency given the current run rate? And also, what's the level of CSeries growth you're actually experiencing?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, and I think I said this in the last quarter, we used up our contingency and a little more as everybody tuned up their production rates in -- at the beginning of that calendar year. And I would say that was kind of across the board. We saw a little b
componenttext: Well, and I think I said this in the last quarter, we used up our contingency and a little more as everybody tuned up their production rates in -- at the beginning of that calendar year. And I would say that was kind of across the board. We saw a little bit additional reduction in globals from what we originally planned. So I haven't seen any changes since then, Myles. We just cut in our fusion flightdeck on the King Airs, if you recall. And I think we're getting pretty good vibes from Cessna in the end market that just got certified in Europe. So we're hopeful that, that will continue to do what it needs to do to sustain rates there. And we'll watch the furlough summer time frame, as I talked about. That's where we get any kind of tweaking of rate. Now recognize that if they do change the rate, that's pretty like in our fiscal year. So I'm not anticipating a heck of a lot of movement here yet. But I think there's still a little bit of risk of adjustments here with the summer timeframe.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: And is the CSeries growing sequentially? Or is it -- is that a growth rate year-on-year that's helping that end market a little bit in terms of comps year-on-year?

componenttext: Yes, the CSeries is growing both sequentially and year-over-year fairly substantially. The issue there is the business jet market for us is so much larger than the regional end market.

Will R&D be about flat for company funded R&D? Or is it going to be down?

componenttext: Within Commercial Systems, it's going to be down year-over-year in total. But we will see that transition from -- in the back half of the year. And I'd say back half of the year, '16 to '15 is going to be about flat from an R&D perspective. One thing I wanted to make sure that we're all focused on, though, is a fair chunk of our savings from the restructuring program is manifesting itself through the research and development expense line because a fair number of people who took the voluntary retirement program were engineers.

componenttext: We are still forecasting differed engineering to be in the neighborhood of $100 million. I think this may be a limit of rest. componenttextpreview: Yes, we recovered all of the product issue, and we recovered that real quickly in the quarter. We did not recover the sales timing issue. In fact, it's one big FMS contract. We've received the contract now, but we received it late enough that we didn't ge
componenttext: Yes, we recovered all of the product issue, and we recovered that real quickly in the quarter. We did not recover the sales timing issue. In fact, it's one big FMS contract. We've received the contract now, but we received it late enough that we didn't get the conversion of the sales. So that's still in our second half to go, to catch up.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Seth Seifman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Seth Seifman with JPMorgan.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the commercial aftermarket in air transport and sort of we have talked in the past about the impact of retirement and some of the structural changes. But what sort of the offset there from Intertra
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the commercial aftermarket in air transport and sort of we have talked in the past about the impact of retirement and some of the structural changes. But what sort of the offset there from Intertrade, first of all? Second of all, what was the contribution therefrom in organic sales in the quarter from the acquisitions? And then third, just kind of more qualitatively. Is there something -- I mean, this is an issue that has affected various companies in the aftermarket in a couple of different time phrases for a couple of different ways. Is there anything specific you see about your products that makes this kind of better or worse or longer-lasting than elsewhere?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's a couple of things that you ought to watch. First of all, the retirement rate does impact the business. If there's fewer retirements, it's harder to find the used parts to turn. On the other hand, we continue to operate those platfor
componenttext: Well, I think there's a couple of things that you ought to watch. First of all, the retirement rate does impact the business. If there's fewer retirements, it's harder to find the used parts to turn. On the other hand, we continue to operate those platforms and drive MRO growth. For our portfolio, it's very wide body driven. So if you look this year, the retirements have abated, but most of that has been in the narrowbody. Some of the 75, 76 and 747-8 retirements are very high content aftermarket platforms for us. So if you want to look at that, I'd look more at the wide body, which may not be typical to other pure company portfolios. What we said all along is the aftermarket MRO is going to be, again, pretty flat to very low single-digit. The offset to that is the used parts sales out of our Intertrade. That comes very lumpy. This past quarter, we're down because we had an engine. We do have another engine sale in the back half of our fiscal year. So we have some things that are going to create a lumpy overall environment because it's really going to be driven more by our Intertrade sales than the underlying MRO.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, great. And then on the inorganic side, the contribution in the quarter?
componenttext: Great, great. And then on the inorganic side, the contribution in the quarter?

componenttext: Yes, it was about -- it came also in the air transport aftermarket. And it was about between 3% or 4% of the growth -- of growth in the -- so offset, let's say a 3% to 4% decline in the air transport aftermarket.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Seth, the only thing I do want to add, Seth, is remember, we knew mandates were coming down. So we did see again mandates the comparable on the engineering sale as headwinds for the quarter in air transport. That mandate headwind is really related to
componenttext: Hey, Seth, the only thing I do want to add, Seth, is remember, we knew mandates were coming down. So we did see again mandates the comparable on the engineering sale as headwinds for the quarter in air transport. That mandate headwind is really related to TCAS changes. The next uptick in mandates we'll start getting will be the ADS-B. Maybe we'll -- we are starting to book some ADS-B orders that's a 2020 mandate. Probably, we'll drive some increases more in the '17 and probably peak in the '18 and '19 timeframe.

componenttext: Well, for this year, we're still fully aligned with Airbus. I think we have 30 airplanes in the year. That's up almost double from last year. So I think we're pretty well aligned with what Airbus is delivering. I think the thing we got to watch is their deliver rate and continued production ramp up. I'm not anticipating any change for this year. Actually, hey, well, let me correct that, I said that wrong. 30 deliveries last year, it's 60 this year. I'm a year behind. Thank you.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Just wanted to go back really quickly on the aftermarket for both and air transport. On this bizjet side, can you talk a little bit about the retrofit work that you're seeing? Just at seems deferred by new products that you'd come out with. But are you seeing retrofits across the entire cabins of this aircraft or just for the parts of these new products that you'd come up with? And then on the Air Transport side, is there -- maybe give us your initial thoughts on initial sparing activity with regard to the ARINC's. Is the macs going to be a less robust from an initial sparing perspective than you would see with an all new aircraft? Just trying to get a sense of whether initial sparing on the macs be anything like what we saw with the 8 7?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it won't per airplane be anything like the 8 7. First of all, the amount of equipment on an air body versus the wide body much less, but the number of aircraft is much higher. So we do expect a meaningful provisioning. And I think that's product lin
componenttext: Well, it won't per airplane be anything like the 8 7. First of all, the amount of equipment on an air body versus the wide body much less, but the number of aircraft is much higher. So we do expect a meaningful provisioning. And I think that's product line specific. Remember, we don't have the display system on the next-generation, the NGEs. We do have that. That's where the display system will be a big part of what the new provisioning. If they're using a common VHF radio to an existing fleet, then we won't see provisioning for that. So I think it is going to be very product specific to what's changed between Angie and but for us it's a lot. It's pretty attractive for the provisioning. The first part of your question, I'm sorry, was?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are continuing to see cabin retrofit. That fueled a lot of our growth last year. I think the cabin retrofits remain solid, but aren't probably growing as much as they are last year. What we're seeing the growth driven by these new fence updates to thin
componenttext: We are continuing to see cabin retrofit. That fueled a lot of our growth last year. I think the cabin retrofits remain solid, but aren't probably growing as much as they are last year. What we're seeing the growth driven by these new fence updates to things like falcon 50s. We've got a new Pro Line Fusion upgrade for King Airs out in the market. And we're again seeing those sales. So we didn't have those products in the market last year. So it's hard for me to tell whether that's product driven or market-driven, probably a little bit of both.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from George Shapiro with Shapiro research.
componenttext: The next question is from George Shapiro with Shapiro research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to pursue the commercial margin a little bit more. If I look at the commercial margin ex R&D, it went down like 500 basis points to 29 6  from 34 6. Now clearly, some of that is affected by the higher sales of the customer funded lower margin bus
componenttext: I wanted to pursue the commercial margin a little bit more. If I look at the commercial margin ex R&D, it went down like 500 basis points to 29 6  from 34 6. Now clearly, some of that is affected by the higher sales of the customer funded lower margin business. But if you can explain a little bit more what's going on there. And then, also, when you go to the third quarter, Patrick, it sounds like you're implying the R&D will be flat with Q3 of last year as opposed to declining $22 million like it did this quarter. So what changes to enable that margin to even stay close to what it is this quarter for commercial?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, George, I think you hit on the biggest margin impact in Commercial Systems, that is the mixed shift. And it was pretty significant. The business -- we always said business jet OEM is very good margin for us and company funded R&D -- or I'm sorry, cu
componenttext: Well, George, I think you hit on the biggest margin impact in Commercial Systems, that is the mixed shift. And it was pretty significant. The business -- we always said business jet OEM is very good margin for us and company funded R&D -- or I'm sorry, customer funded R&D comes at little to no margin. So that was the biggest shift in margin for us. Now included in that is also a few million dollars associated with I'll call them acquisition-related SG&A cost that Commercial Systems is absorbing as well. So you got the compounding effect of those acquisition-related SG&A costs. And as we progress further, we're going to see sequential growth in Commercial Systems. That growth is going to become -- coming from higher margin product. And so we should see, I'll say, incremental earnings to offset that lift in company funded R&D.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then one just one quick other one. I'm assuming or guessing, Patrick, that the gain in the IMS business was maybe $3 million or $4 million.

componenttext: The claims? Yes, I think it was around $3 million.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from David Strauss with UBS.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, I know it's a little bit early to think about 2017. But you've had this target out there for high single-digit growth at Commercial Systems on the future. Based on everything you know today, given the pressure on business jet, we had 777 rate cut a
componenttext: Kelly, I know it's a little bit early to think about 2017. But you've had this target out there for high single-digit growth at Commercial Systems on the future. Based on everything you know today, given the pressure on business jet, we had 777 rate cut announced, do we get somewhere close to that? Or is that out of the question? Just trying to think about modeling Commercial Systems on a go-forward basis.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it is a little early to make that call. We've certainly seen a lower Business Aviation production rates than what we anticipated when we put that guidance out. But I'll also say there's been good stuff. We've seen increased rates in the air transpor
componenttext: Well, it is a little early to make that call. We've certainly seen a lower Business Aviation production rates than what we anticipated when we put that guidance out. But I'll also say there's been good stuff. We've seen increased rates in the air transport. We've seen increased content on some new aircraft coming into the market. Looks like CSeries is now going to move from the development phase into the production phase. So I don't want to tell you what a rate is right now because I'm still waiting to see the final detail from my team. But there's been puts and takes. And I think over the long run, they should be able to balance each other out.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Patrick, a follow-up on working capital. You talked about it trending better in the second half of the year. Can you just give a little more detail there what you're expecting -- what we should see from advances and I guess, production inventory. I think
componenttext: Patrick, a follow-up on working capital. You talked about it trending better in the second half of the year. Can you just give a little more detail there what you're expecting -- what we should see from advances and I guess, production inventory. I think you've already touched on preproduction.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did see a bit of a buildup in the production inventory. And I would say it was in anticipation of a strong second half for Government Systems in terms of sales. So this buildup inventory, that was part of the working capital. I expect that to norm
componenttext: Yes, we did see a bit of a buildup in the production inventory. And I would say it was in anticipation of a strong second half for Government Systems in terms of sales. So this buildup inventory, that was part of the working capital. I expect that to normalize over the course of the balance of the year. And I think the customer payments -- the customer advances, I think we viewed as being a headwind for the year when we came into the year. I think it's probably going to abate a little bit in the second half, but not a lot. I think the improvement you're going to see in working capital is going to be largely the production inventory. So now if I was the point to a risk to our cash flow is the fact that we are so back-end loaded on sales that making sure that we get the sales booked and cash collected by the end of the fourth quarter is going to be the challenge that we're all focused on.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ron Epstein with Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is from Ron Epstein with Bank of America.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Big picture question for you, Kelly. One of the themes that seem to emerge at Hamburg this year, even more so than previous years, was the connected airplane and so on and so forth. Can you just wax a little bit on that opportunity for Collins thinking ab
componenttext: Big picture question for you, Kelly. One of the themes that seem to emerge at Hamburg this year, even more so than previous years, was the connected airplane and so on and so forth. Can you just wax a little bit on that opportunity for Collins thinking about high-bandwidth connectivity to the airplane and how ARINC's mission for that because it seems like there position pretty well, but I just wanted to get your take on it.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we are positioned well, and we are -- I mean, raising growth in the connectivity today. We've booked our first 4 customers, 2 in Business Aviation and 2 in the Air Transport market for Global Express, which is then you broadband Inmarsat capability.
componenttext: Well, we are positioned well, and we are -- I mean, raising growth in the connectivity today. We've booked our first 4 customers, 2 in Business Aviation and 2 in the Air Transport market for Global Express, which is then you broadband Inmarsat capability. And we're working a lot of proposals now. We do see this as a big growth opportunity. And recognize, Ron, that today, we really don't provide much cabin-based broadband connectivity in the markets. So that's all growth opportunity for us. We're very strong in the flight deck connectivity, but less so in the cabin. And GX will present a big opportunity for us. And we're also working with OneWeb rep for a next-generation program where will the exclusive supplier of the radio equipment and also a value-added reseller. And we're going to be bringing that onto the airbus platforms in the future. So I'm excited about it. It's happening. There's no question there's going to be strong demand for broadband connectivity. The connectivity solutions that are out there today that aren't broadband just aren't meeting the connected world needs that we all have. And once that happens, it opens the door to applications and services. And we're also focused at providing those kinds of capabilities where once you have broadband connectivity, you can move information easier on and off the airplane and provide additional services for either maintenance or operation improvements for the airlines going forward. So it's one of the drivers as to why we think the ARINC acquisition is a great value driver for the long term for our company. And I'm excited about the growth of our Information Management Services portfolio and the opportunities going forward.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe just one natural follow-on, if you can even speculate or maybe even know. What's the required investment to kind of to grow in that area? I mean, is it -- how would you quantify that?
componenttext: So maybe just one natural follow-on, if you can even speculate or maybe even know. What's the required investment to kind of to grow in that area? I mean, is it -- how would you quantify that?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would put it in -- let me just put it in categories. There's new radios. So you've got to develop a radio equipment as compatible with these new broadband satellites. A lot of investment inattentive technology associated with -- again, with these
componenttext: Well, I would put it in -- let me just put it in categories. There's new radios. So you've got to develop a radio equipment as compatible with these new broadband satellites. A lot of investment inattentive technology associated with -- again, with these new satellites and being an efficient integration. There is new certification cost both in forward fit as well as retrofits. So we have, to go get FTCs. So for example, for these 4 launch customers that I've talked about, we are investing now in getting the STCs done, getting the certification baseline to retrofit those aircraft. So those are the categories of investment. And they're very similar to what investments we do with other radio systems in the market. So I think we know what those investments are and their plumbed in our R&D plans as we look forward.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: The next question is from Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to follow up to George's question, that's the biggest declines I think I've ever seen in your margin before are the company under R&D and deferred engineering amortization. To what extent was that also impacted by the fact that it sounds like most of y
componenttext: So to follow up to George's question, that's the biggest declines I think I've ever seen in your margin before are the company under R&D and deferred engineering amortization. To what extent was that also impacted by the fact that it sounds like most of your commercial revenue gain came in new program 787, A350, CSeries. Is that lower margin business? And then, as you look at the second half, I mean, you're going to have higher deferred engineering amortization, higher company funded R&D kind of looks to me like the mix continues to shift towards those newer programs. Can the commercial margins improve over this 21% or 22%?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I'd say I think Commercial Systems margin in the back half of the year is going to be pretty close to what it was for the first half of the year. I don't see it changing significantly, Cai. Now I do want to, I guess, clarify couple of points. E
componenttext: Yes, well, I'd say I think Commercial Systems margin in the back half of the year is going to be pretty close to what it was for the first half of the year. I don't see it changing significantly, Cai. Now I do want to, I guess, clarify couple of points. Even though the margin headwind that we had from this mix shift was significant. And we're talking about from very high margin product sales to lower margin customer funded R&D. That was a big impact. And I think, going forward, we'll still see some of that mix issue. But it will be quite as dramatic. And I think we feel pretty comfortable that of the margin targets that we laid out for commercial systems are achievable.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to add to that, Cai. The margin is what Patrick said. It's losing the bizjet revenue and increasing the AR or engineering revenues, it's not a mix of new products coming in the market. We have very good profitability with the new products that's comi
componenttext: Just to add to that, Cai. The margin is what Patrick said. It's losing the bizjet revenue and increasing the AR or engineering revenues, it's not a mix of new products coming in the market. We have very good profitability with the new products that's coming in the market. It's part of our common product line strategy where we're reusing. So you shouldn't view 787 any more as a new product. We've been in rate manufacturing for that one. We're now at 12-month rate. So that's very, very good performance from us. And I'm not worried about the product versus old product mix and looking forward.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. But if the commercial -- company are and these flat year-over-year, deferred engineering is going to be up. You got to be up 200, 300 basis points in your margin before those items in commercial just to hold relatively flat. So what happens in the
componenttext: Right. But if the commercial -- company are and these flat year-over-year, deferred engineering is going to be up. You got to be up 200, 300 basis points in your margin before those items in commercial just to hold relatively flat. So what happens in the second half to kind of give you that margin lift, free those expense items that you're talking about versus the second quarter?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I didn't say it was -- of the company funded R&D is going to be flat. It's going to be down a little bit. It'll be closer to flat for the third quarter. So that's part of the answer. And then the other answer is continued cost reductio
componenttext: Well, first of all, I didn't say it was -- of the company funded R&D is going to be flat. It's going to be down a little bit. It'll be closer to flat for the third quarter. So that's part of the answer. And then the other answer is continued cost reductions.  We'll continue to see benefit from the retirement program flowing through the numbers. If you think about it from an operations perspective, that benefit gets deferred by a quarter because it's an inventory. So we'll see that benefit flow through as well.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Patrick, maybe just a sort of, hopefully, round that out on the margins. You also mentioned, I think, looking for a sequentially roughly flat total segment margin. Maybe if you could just talk about that by segment. When even if he discussed the progression and through the end of the year by segment just given in there are a bunch of moving pieces in the commercial segment. It sounds like you gained 200 basis points or so at IMS, which I would assume doesn't repeat and the government growth rate changes a lot. So maybe it'll be helpful to just discuss it by segment.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what you're going to see -- you're right. The IMS segment margins were higher than they normally would be. So I think what you just see is the IMS, I'll say, more normalizing in that 15% to 16% range. I think Commercial Systems, as I mentioned, wi
componenttext: I think what you're going to see -- you're right. The IMS segment margins were higher than they normally would be. So I think what you just see is the IMS, I'll say, more normalizing in that 15% to 16% range. I think Commercial Systems, as I mentioned, will be pretty flat quarter-to-quarter, Q3 and Q4. And what you'll see in Government Systems is that the margin is going to maybe tick up a little bit in the third quarter not much and the bulk of the margin expansion is going to be in the fourth quarter.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Sorry, did you say commercial flat 3Q and then flat again 4Q?

componenttext: Yes, pretty much.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And how 4Q loaded is the free cash outlook just given the year-to-date number there and what you said about the collection risks?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Unfortunately, every year, it seems like our cash flow is fourth quarter loaded, and it continues to be. And I'd say, if anything, it's probably a little bit more, a little heavier than normal just because of the sales profile we're looking at. So ye
componenttext: Yes. Unfortunately, every year, it seems like our cash flow is fourth quarter loaded, and it continues to be. And I'd say, if anything, it's probably a little bit more, a little heavier than normal just because of the sales profile we're looking at. So yes, very heavily weighted toward the fourth quarter.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Richard Safran with Buckingham Research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just switch topics here. I was interested in this HMS Manpack contract. Can you tell me a bit of a multipart question. When you delivered the 30 radios, if only production is supposed to commence in '17, does that imply a down select this year? And t
componenttext: I'll just switch topics here. I was interested in this HMS Manpack contract. Can you tell me a bit of a multipart question. When you delivered the 30 radios, if only production is supposed to commence in '17, does that imply a down select this year? And is this a winner take all type of thing? Meaning, if you did win, would the $12.7 billion over 10 years all go to Collins?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. A lot of questions there. So that me walk through the program. First of all, we want to the initial award with 2 other suppliers. We will delivering a roughly 30 radios, I think, into the Army. They'll take those through 2 test regimes, a developmen
componenttext: Okay. A lot of questions there. So that me walk through the program. First of all, we want to the initial award with 2 other suppliers. We will delivering a roughly 30 radios, I think, into the Army. They'll take those through 2 test regimes, a development test regime and a contract test regime, to validate those radios against the overall requirements. So there will be no revenues in fiscal '16 associated with that program because these are free of charge radios. We're just providing them to the Army to go through the test. From the results of the test, then they will go to what I would call a call for improvement for the participants who past the test to then provide in a updated price for the next fiscal year buy. So I would say, Richard, it'll probably be this time next year before they make that decision. Their current plan is that they would down select from 3. If there are still 3 viable suppliers through the test phase, they would down select from 3 to 2 for that annual buy. Obviously, if that this time last year, there's actually very little revenue opportunity next year either because the revenue will go with the radios are delivered. So it really has moved to an '18 -- really, an '18 growth item. The other thing I'll say is that $12.7 billion, while I like the top line numbers. What that is, is that's the max quantities in every case other the IDIQ contracts. So think of this contract as a huge Matrix with max quantities all priced and they're all added together. This is not going to be a $12.7 billion contract in my mind. However, it'll be very significant, maybe more like $4 billion to $5 billion of revenue. How much comes to us depends on common to contractors. How much -- what percentage of that we went? We've said, hey, look, we can easily see $100 million a year kind of a revenue stream from this program, if not more.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Rockwell Collins Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and management introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Rockwell Collins' Vice Pr
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Rockwell Collins Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. 
For opening remarks and management introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Rockwell Collins' Vice President of Investor Relations, Ryan Miller. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning to all of you on the call. With me on the line this morning are Rockwell Collins' Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Kelly Ortberg; and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Patrick Allen.Tod
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning to all of you on the call. With me on the line this morning are Rockwell Collins' Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Kelly Ortberg; and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Patrick Allen.
Today's call is being webcast, and you can view the slides we'll be presenting today at our website at www.rockwellcollins.com under the Investor Relations tab. These slides include certain non-GAAP financial information and a reconciliation to the related GAAP measure.
Please note, today's presentation and webcast will include certain projections and statements that are forward looking. Actual results may differ materially from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including those detailed on Slide 2 of this webcast presentation and from time to time in the company's Securities and Exchange Commission filings. These forward-looking statements are made as of today, and the company assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements.
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Kelly.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Ryan, and good morning, everyone. With 2 quarters down, our fiscal year 2016 is progressing directionally as we expected. As we indicated in October and again in our last quarterly call, this is definitely a first-half, second-half story. An
componenttext:
Well, thanks, Ryan, and good morning, everyone. With 2 quarters down, our fiscal year 2016 is progressing directionally as we expected. As we indicated in October and again in our last quarterly call, this is definitely a first-half, second-half story. And because we saw it coming, we've been very transparent about the Business Aviation production rates as well as the Government Systems program timing and the impact on our top line sales profile for the year. 
We also, as you know, initiated a restructuring program to help sustain our bottom line performance. This restructuring was essentially complete in the first quarter, and I'm pleased to report that it's now delivering the savings that we expected. 
Now the largest shift in growth from the first half to the second half of the year is in our Government Systems business. So let me start here and give you an update on the metrics I outlined last quarter relative to that growth. 
In the last call, I said that about 60% of the back-half growth was already in backlog or coming from annual buys of follow-on business. This category has now grown from 60% last quarter to 77% at the end of the second quarter. Again, this is all funded activities, so I don't see much risk here, and I'm pleased that we're making the progress in firming this up. 
Now the second category of growth is in programs that we have won, but have yet to be awarded. And this has decreased from 25% last quarter to 17% this quarter. The only risk in this area is moving these programs through the contracting action in the firm backlog. And at this point, I don't see anything that would keep us from firming up the 17%. 
And then the third category, which is the balance of the second half growth, is coming from programs that we have yet to go out and win. This category has decreased from 15% last quarter to now making up only 6% of our planned growth. 
As I look at all these metrics, we're right in line with our historical anticipated sales for this time of the year. So despite the challenging first half, we have good line of sight to the second half growth for Government Systems. And as a reminder, the fourth quarter is always the biggest in terms of sales and margins, and I do expect our growth rate to be the highest in the fourth quarter as well.
Now turning to Commercial Systems. The first half went about as expected, but the aftermarket components are a little different from what we originally anticipated. The Business Aviation has performed better than expected, and the air transport aftermarket has been softer. As this turned out, the 2 have essentially offset each other for the first half of the year, so our overall aftermarket performance remains on track. 
The strength in the Business Aviation aftermarket has been driven by mandates, which we expected, but also by stronger-than-expected cockpit retrofits. We introduced some new avionics aftermarket products late last year, and they're selling quite well. The weaker air transport aftermarket is being driven by the impacts of recycling, and we're also dealing with the impacts of more aggregators in the service market. I believe these are indicative of structural changes in how the airlines are managing their MRO needs, and we should no longer be expecting MRO to grow at traffic rates at least for the foreseeable future. 
Now air transport OEM rates are progressing as planned with production ramping for the 787, the A350 and the Airbus narrow-bodies. These increases are partially offset by rate reductions in the A330. Now business jet OEM rates remain consistent with last quarter. And if you recall, I said in the last call, that the summer shutdown period is when we would likely see business jet reductions if there are going to be any more that happened this year. So that remains a watch area for us for the next quarter. 
Finally, let me turn to our Information Management Services business. This past quarter, we delivered 5% sales growth and really strong operating performance with margins improving by 370 basis points. Our core aviation business grew 8% for the quarter, driving the profitability for that business. 
While this is great performance, our top line to date is a bit lower than I expected. We are seeing weaker demand for Business Aviation international trip support, which has been hit pretty hard in Russia, China and in oil-producing countries. Without a pick-up here, we'll probably see our IMS business grow a bit slower for the full year than originally expected. We are expecting, though, to see growth in the second half from the non-aviation portion of the business. And I do want to point out that the better-than-expected profitability should more than offset any top line weakness in our IMS portfolio for the year. 
So having walked through the 3 business segments, let me now turn to our longer-term outlook. We achieved several very important milestones on programs that drive our long-term growth. These include the first flight of the Boeing 737 MAX, with our new standard equipment all delivered on time and working very well. The first refueling flight was performed on the KC-46 tanker validating both our Avionics and the refueling mission package, which is a first using 3D image technology. And we're also selected as one of the suppliers on the U.S. Army's Manpack radio program, which is a key step towards bringing this large growth opportunity to reality.
Also in March, we are recognized by Ethisphere Institute as one of 2016's most ethical companies, and this is the seventh year in a row receiving this award. So these achievements all demonstrate how we're striving to be the most trusted source of aviation and high integrity solutions in the world, and it's really some good reasons to be optimistic about the future of our company.
Now before I turn it over to Patrick, I do want to address an administrative item. For years, we've issued our next fiscal year financial guidance in September. And I've received feedback from many of you that it would make a lot more sense for us to issue the guidance when we announced our fourth quarter results, which typically happens at the end of October. So this is exactly what we plan to do for this coming year. Hopefully, this will make things more efficient for the investment community as well as for Rockwell Collins, and it'll allow us to better align with the OEMs on production rates, and we'll be able to discuss year-on-year financial guidance because our full year results for fiscal '16 will be complete at that time.
So with that out of the way, let me turn the call over to Patrick to walk us through the quarterly details.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kelly, and good morning to everyone as well. I'd now like to walk you through today's presentation slides that summarize our results for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. I'd like to begin on Slide 3, where we have our total company second quarte
componenttext:
Thanks, Kelly, and good morning to everyone as well. I'd now like to walk you through today's presentation slides that summarize our results for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. I'd like to begin on Slide 3, where we have our total company second quarter sales, earnings per share, income from continuing operations and shares outstanding. 
Total company sales for the quarter decreased $30 million or 2% compared to the second quarter last year, primarily due to lower Government Systems sales. Income from continuing operations increased $9 million or 6% and earnings per share from continuing operations increased $0.08 or 7% compared to the same period last year. The increase in income from continuing operations and earnings per share from continuing operations was primarily due to lower income tax expense due to permitted extension of Federal Research and Development Tax Credit. 
As we turn to Slide 4, Commercial Systems achieved revenue of $611 million in the quarter, down 1% compared to the same period last year. Sales related to aircraft OEMs decreased $17 million or 5% to $353 million, primarily due to lower business aircraft OEM production rates, unfavorable airline selectable equipment mix and lower Airbus A330 production rates, all partially offset by higher customer-funded development program sales, higher deliveries in support of the Airbus A350 and Boeing 787 production rate ramps and higher Bombardier CSeries sales in support of its entry into service later this year.
Aftermarket sales increased $14 million or 6%, primarily due to higher business jet avionics retrofit mandate sales and higher inorganic sales from the acquisition of the International Communications Group. 
Commercial Systems' operating earnings decreased $7 million with operating margins declining 80 basis points from 22.9% to 22.1%. Operating earnings and margins decreased in the prior year, primarily due to sales mix as lower-margin customer-funded development sales increased and higher-margin business jet OEM sales decreased. In addition, SG&A cost increased from higher costs associated with recent acquisitions. These items were partially offset by a lower company-funded research and development expense and cost savings initiatives from previously announced restructuring plans.
Moving on to Slide 5. Government Systems' overall revenue decreased by 5% to $538 million, driven by lower rotary wing hardware sales, lower sales from simulation and training programs, the wind-down of an international electronic warfare program and lower international targeting system deliveries. 
Government Systems' second quarter operating earnings decreased $6 million to $108 million, resulting in an operating margin that was flat with the second quarter of the prior year at 20.1%. The decreased operating earnings resulted from the lower sales volume, partially offset by lower company-funded research and development expense and cost saving initiatives from previously announced restructuring plans.
Turning to Slide 6. Information Management Services' sales increased 5% over the prior year as commercial and Business Aviation services sales increased 8%, while the nonaviation-related businesses were slightly down compared to last year. Information Management Services' second quarter operating earnings increased $7 million to  $29 million, resulting in an operating margin of 17.9% compared to 14.2% in the second quarter last year. The increase in operating earnings and margin was due to the incremental earnings and the higher sales volume as well as a favorable resolution of some certain prior year claims associated with international business jet support services.
Looking next to Slide 7. We show year-to-date results for revenue, income from continuing operations, earnings per share and operating cash flow. Through the second quarter, we generated $45 million of operating cash flow compared to $132 million last year. The decrease in cash generation resulted from the lower pretax earnings and net unfavorable changes to working capital, which were primarily due to the timing of sales related to advanced payments from customers. These items are partially offset by lower tax payments. 
Slide 8 provides an update of our total R&D investment. Total spend decreased from $489 million in the first 6 months of fiscal 2015 to $470 million in the first 6 months -- I'm sorry, $489 million in the first 6 months of fiscal 2015 to $470 million in the first 6 months of FY '16. Company-funded R&D decreased $43 million due to lower business jet development cost in Commercial Systems and lower Software Defined Radio development cost in Government Systems. Customer-funded research and development expense increased $15 million due to higher development cost for regional jet development programs in Commercial Systems, partially offset by the wind-down of an international electronic warfare program in Government Systems. Preproduction engineering investment net increased to the higher costs incurred for military program in Government Systems.
Moving to Slide 9, we show the status of our capital structure as of the end of the second quarter compared to the end of last year. During the first 6 months of FY '16, our debt-to-EBITDA ratio increased to 2.1 from 1.7 at year-end. The increase was primarily due to an increase in commercial paper, as the first half of the year are typically late cash flows. I expect this level of debt to come down over the balance of the year as a larger portion of our cash flow is traditionally generated later in the year, and we pay down a portion of that short-term debt.
The updated status of the share repurchase program as of the end of the second quarter is detailed on Slide 10. During the second quarter, we repurchased 1.2 million shares at an average cost of $85.03. Our repurchase authority remaining at the end of the quarter was $192 million. 
Now on to Slide 11 where we provide a summary of our fiscal year 2016 financial guidance, which remains unchanged from the guidance we provided last quarter. We do now have some clarity on when we expect to benefit from the tax planning strategies that we initially guided would benefit the second half of fiscal '16. These tax-funding strategies, which entail utilizing capital loss carryforwards from prior years, is now expected to benefit our third fiscal quarter. Our tax rate for the third quarter will likely be in the mid-teens, and the tax rate for the fourth quarter will likely be in the neighborhood of about 30%. We still expect the full year tax rate to be between 22% and 23%. 
I also wanted to talk about the trajectory of our operating margins over the last half of the year, and we're expecting operating margins to be about flat sequentially from the second quarter to the third quarter. We do expect the overall business will return to growth in the third quarter and net growth will drive incremental earnings. But we will also be shifting our engineering expense from deferred engineering to company-funded engineering, resulting in a fairly flat sequential total operating margins. 
As we look to the fourth quarter, you should expect to see more incremental margin growth due to the higher growth rate in sales that Kelly talked about a little earlier. 
That completes my review of the financial results and projections. So Ryan, back to you to kick off the Q&A session.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question is from Howard Rubel with Jefferies.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, you talked a little bit about bizjet aftermarket and some of the positives and also some of the concerns or change in dynamics in commercial. Specifically with bizjets, can you talk about whether it was categories and what kind of visibility you mi
componenttext: Kelly, you talked a little bit about bizjet aftermarket and some of the positives and also some of the concerns or change in dynamics in commercial. Specifically with bizjets, can you talk about whether it was categories and what kind of visibility you might have? And then also the same for the commercial market.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look at those 2, the commercial and bizjet aftermarket, I recognize it's kind of counterintuitive to the health of those underlying markets. But in Business Aviation, we continue to see very strong mandate growth this quarter, which we did exp
componenttext: Yes, if you look at those 2, the commercial and bizjet aftermarket, I recognize it's kind of counterintuitive to the health of those underlying markets. But in Business Aviation, we continue to see very strong mandate growth this quarter, which we did expect, as I said in the opening remarks. But we also introduced some fans upgrades, avionics upgrades into the market. And that -- again, that is selling very well. And I'm hopeful that, that will continue to sell and maybe give us some upside opportunity here in the balance of the year. In air transport, it's kind of the opposite story. We had mandate headwinds in air transport. Last year, we had a big engine sales, which didn't repeat. So we had a little bit of a comparable issue on that. If I strip all of the onetime activities as well as our Intertrade use business sales out of air transport, just look at the fundamental MRO. We've been roughly flat the first 2 quarters in fundamental MRO, and I think that's about what we're going to see. They're flat to very low single-digit growth in that underlying MRO business, as we deal with the new recycling phenomenon that's here to stay.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just this one follow-up, a little bit different. You talked about LRS-B and you had some other military wins. Is there change in focus? And can you add anything with respect to the LRS-B opportunity?
componenttext: And then just this one follow-up, a little bit different. You talked about LRS-B and you had some other military wins. Is there change in focus? And can you add anything with respect to the LRS-B opportunity?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, no, I can't add anything on that other than we're pleased to be on the Northrop Grumman team. That's about all I can say there. I wouldn't say, Howard, it's a change in our focus. I just think it's a change in the opportunities. The market dynamics
componenttext: Well, no, I can't add anything on that other than we're pleased to be on the Northrop Grumman team. That's about all I can say there. I wouldn't say, Howard, it's a change in our focus. I just think it's a change in the opportunities. The market dynamics are getting better. We're certainly seeing lift in things like JDM production rates associated with what's going on in the world. We are still struggling with the timing of getting things through the contracting action. That didn't improve. And as you look at our government business for the first half of the year, we guided at down mid single-digit. We ended up at 8% down. So we are a little behind where we wanted to be, and it's mostly getting some of these selected programs through the contracting action a few for military sales specific programs. But we've got good visibility to that. I'm pretty confident we'll be able to get that done by the end of the fiscal year.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
