componenttext: In other words, there will be some contribution, I guess. And then just last quarter, you talked about 5 percentage points impact on the Government Systems for a supplier issue and the order timing. Were both of those resolved in the quarter? And did you cover all those sales?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we recovered all of the product issue, and we recovered that real quickly in the quarter. We did not recover the sales timing issue. In fact, it's one big FMS contract. We've received the contract now, but we received it late enough that we didn't ge
componenttext: Yes, we recovered all of the product issue, and we recovered that real quickly in the quarter. We did not recover the sales timing issue. In fact, it's one big FMS contract. We've received the contract now, but we received it late enough that we didn't get the conversion of the sales. So that's still in our second half to go to catch up.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Seth Seifman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Seth Seifman with JPMorgan.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the commercial aftermarket in air transport and sort of we have talked in the past about the impact of retirement and some of the structural changes. But what's sort of the offset there from Intert
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about the commercial aftermarket in air transport and sort of we have talked in the past about the impact of retirement and some of the structural changes. But what's sort of the offset there from Intertrade, first of all? Second of all, what was the contribution there from inorganic sales in the quarter from the acquisitions? And then third, just kind of more qualitatively. Is there something -- I mean, this is an issue that has affected various companies in the aftermarket in a couple of different -- at different time periods and for a couple of different ways. Is there anything specific you see about your products that makes this kind of better or worse or longer-lasting than elsewhere?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's a couple of things that you ought to watch. First of all, the retirement rate does impact the business. If there's fewer retirements, it's harder to find the used parts to turn. On the other hand, we continue to operate those platfor
componenttext: Well, I think there's a couple of things that you ought to watch. First of all, the retirement rate does impact the business. If there's fewer retirements, it's harder to find the used parts to turn. On the other hand, we continue to operate those platforms and drive MRO growth. For our portfolio, it's very wide-body driven. So if you look this year, the retirements have abated, but most of that has been in the narrow-body. Some of the 75, 76 and 747-8 retirements are very high-content aftermarket platforms for us. So if you want to look at that, I'd look more at the wide-body, which may not be typical to other pure company portfolios. What we said all along is the aftermarket MRO is going to be, again, pretty flat to very low single digit. The offset to that is the used parts sales out of our Intertrade. That comes very lumpy. This past quarter, we were down because we had an engine a year ago. We do have another engine sale in the back half of our fiscal year. So we have some things that are going to create a lumpy overall environment, because it's really going to be driven more by our Intertrade sales than the underlying MRO.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, great. And then on the inorganic side, the contribution in the quarter?
componenttext: Great, great. And then on the inorganic side, the contribution in the quarter?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was about -- it came mostly in the air transport aftermarket, and it was about between 3% or 4% of the growth -- of growth in the -- so it offset, let's say, a 3% to 4% decline in the air transport aftermarket.
componenttext: Yes, it was about -- it came mostly in the air transport aftermarket, and it was about between 3% or 4% of the growth -- of growth in the -- so it offset, let's say, a 3% to 4% decline in the air transport aftermarket.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seth, the only thing I do want to add, Seth, is remember, we knew mandates were coming down. So we did see, again, mandates, the comparable on the engineering sale as headwinds for the quarter in air transport. That mandate headwind is really related to T
componenttext: Seth, the only thing I do want to add, Seth, is remember, we knew mandates were coming down. So we did see, again, mandates, the comparable on the engineering sale as headwinds for the quarter in air transport. That mandate headwind is really related to TCAS changes. The next uptick in mandates we'll start getting will be the ADS-B. Maybe we'll -- we are starting to book some ADS-B orders. That's a 2020 mandate. Probably we'll drive some increases more in the '17 and probably peak in the '18, '19 time frame.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And I guess maybe since we're talking about the topic, would it be in the first half of your fiscal '17 that we'd see provisioning for the MAX start to pick up?
componenttext: Great. And I guess maybe since we're talking about the topic, would it be in the first half of your fiscal '17 that we'd see provisioning for the MAX start to pick up?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think a material provisioning, that's when you'll start to see a pick up. We may actually see a little bit of provisioning with the initial customer here by the end of the year. We're working that right now.
componenttext: Yes, I think a material provisioning, that's when you'll start to see a pick up. We may actually see a little bit of provisioning with the initial customer here by the end of the year. We're working that right now.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Peter Arment with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: The next question is from Peter Arment with Sterne Agee.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, could you give us a little more color on what you're seeing out of the A350, kind of the run rates? You've -- historically, Rockwell has always been kind of ahead of the OEMs in terms of the run rates. What are you seeing in that program right now?
componenttext: Kelly, could you give us a little more color on what you're seeing out of the A350, kind of the run rates? You've -- historically, Rockwell has always been kind of ahead of the OEMs in terms of the run rates. What are you seeing in that program right now?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, for this year, we're still fully aligned with Airbus. I think we have 30 airplanes in the year. That's up almost double from last year. So I think we're pretty well aligned with what Airbus is delivering. I think the thing we got to watch is their d
componenttext: Well, for this year, we're still fully aligned with Airbus. I think we have 30 airplanes in the year. That's up almost double from last year. So I think we're pretty well aligned with what Airbus is delivering. I think the thing we got to watch is their delivery rate and continued production ramp-up. I'm not anticipating any change for this year.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, if I could just...
componenttext: Okay, if I could just...

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, let me correct that. I said that wrong. 30 deliveries last year; it's 60 this year. I'm a year behind. Thank you.
componenttext: Actually, let me correct that. I said that wrong. 30 deliveries last year; it's 60 this year. I'm a year behind. Thank you.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, if I could ask, just to sneak in one follow-up, just unrelated but, Kelly, you mentioned kind of the -- you gave us a lot of color on the Government Systems line of sight, the sight of growth for the back half of the year. What are you seeing from an
componenttext: No, if I could ask, just to sneak in one follow-up, just unrelated but, Kelly, you mentioned kind of the -- you gave us a lot of color on the Government Systems line of sight, the sight of growth for the back half of the year. What are you seeing from an international defense perspective? Are you seeing any change in like the pacing of awards just given the reset in the oil price deck? Or are you seeing any impact there?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not really, nothing out of the Middle East. And everything continues to track pretty much to plan. The -- where we're seeing delays is actually getting through the foreign military sale process, which is a really U.S. issue and less the end customer i
componenttext: No, not really, nothing out of the Middle East. And everything continues to track pretty much to plan. The -- where we're seeing delays is actually getting through the foreign military sale process, which is a really U.S. issue and less the end customer issue in getting through that contracting action.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Gursky with Citi.
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to go back really quickly on the aftermarket for both bizjet and air transport. On bizjet side, can you talk a little bit about the retrofit work that you're seeing? You suggest it's been spurred by new products that you've come out with, bu
componenttext: I just wanted to go back really quickly on the aftermarket for both bizjet and air transport. On bizjet side, can you talk a little bit about the retrofit work that you're seeing? You suggest it's been spurred by new products that you've come out with, but are you seeing retrofits across the entire cabins of this aircraft or just for the parts of these new products that you've come up with? And then on the air transport side, is there -- maybe give us your initial thoughts on the initial sparing activity with regard to the MAX. Is the MAX going to be a less robust from an initial sparing perspective than we would see with an all new aircraft? Just trying to get a sense of whether initial sparing on the MAX will be anything like what we saw with the 87?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it won't, per airplane, be anything like the 87. First of all, the amount of equipment on a narrow-body versus a wide-body is much less, but the number of aircraft is much higher. So we do expect a meaningful provisioning. And I think that's product
componenttext: Well, it won't, per airplane, be anything like the 87. First of all, the amount of equipment on a narrow-body versus a wide-body is much less, but the number of aircraft is much higher. So we do expect a meaningful provisioning. And I think that's product line specific. Remember, we don't have the display system on the next generation. The NGEs, we do have that. That's where the display system will be a big part of what the new provisioning. If they're using a common VHF radio to an existing fleet, then we won't see provisioning for that. So I think it is going to be very product specific to what's changed between an NG and a MAX. But for us, it's a lot. It's pretty attractive for the provisioning. The first part of your question, I'm sorry, was...

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Business jet for retrofits.
componenttext: Business jet for retrofits.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The business jet...
componenttext: The business jet...

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bizjet retrofits. We are continuing to see cabin retrofits. That fueled a lot of our growth last year. I think the cabin retrofits remain solid but aren't probably growing as much as they are last year. What we are seeing the growth driven by are these ne
componenttext: Bizjet retrofits. We are continuing to see cabin retrofits. That fueled a lot of our growth last year. I think the cabin retrofits remain solid but aren't probably growing as much as they are last year. What we are seeing the growth driven by are these new FANS updates to things like Falcon 50s. We've got a new Pro Line Fusion upgrade for King Airs out in the market, and we're again seeing those sell. So we didn't have those products in the market last year, so it's hard for me to tell whether that's product-driven or market-driven, probably a little bit of both.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.
componenttext: The next question is from George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wanted to pursue the commercial margin a little bit more. If I look at the commercial margin ex R&D, it went down like 500 basis points to 29.6%, from 34.6%. Now clearly, some of that is affected by the higher sales of the customer-funded lower-mar
componenttext: Yes, I wanted to pursue the commercial margin a little bit more. If I look at the commercial margin ex R&D, it went down like 500 basis points to 29.6%, from 34.6%. Now clearly, some of that is affected by the higher sales of the customer-funded lower-margin business, but if you can explain a little bit more what's going on there. And then also when you go to the third quarter, Patrick, it sounds like you're implying the R&D will be flat with Q3 of last year as opposed to declining $22 million like it did this quarter. So what changes to enable that margin to even stay close to what it is this quarter for commercial?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, George, I think you've hit on the biggest margin impact in Commercial Systems, that is the mixed shift. It was pretty significant. The business -- we always said business jet OEM is very good margin for us and company-funded R&D -- or I'm sorry, cus
componenttext: Well, George, I think you've hit on the biggest margin impact in Commercial Systems, that is the mixed shift. It was pretty significant. The business -- we always said business jet OEM is very good margin for us and company-funded R&D -- or I'm sorry, customer-funded R&D comes at little to no margin. So that was the biggest shift in margin for us. Now included in that is also a few million dollars associated with, I'll call them, acquisition-related SG&A costs that Commercial Systems is absorbing as well. So you've got the compounding effect of those acquisition-related SG&A costs. And as we progress further, we're going to see sequential growth in Commercial Systems. That growth is going to become -- coming from higher margin product. And so we should see, I'll say, incremental earnings to offset that lift in company-funded R&D.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one just one quick other one. I'm assuming or guessing, Patrick, that the gain in the IMS business was maybe $3 million or $4 million.
componenttext: Okay. And then one just one quick other one. I'm assuming or guessing, Patrick, that the gain in the IMS business was maybe $3 million or $4 million.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The claims, yes. I think it was around $3 million.
componenttext: The claims, yes. I think it was around $3 million.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from David Strauss with UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from David Strauss with UBS.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, I know it's a little bit early to think about 2017, but you've had this target out there for high single-digit growth at Commercial Systems out in the future. Based on everything you know today, given the pressure on business jet, we've had a 777 r
componenttext: Kelly, I know it's a little bit early to think about 2017, but you've had this target out there for high single-digit growth at Commercial Systems out in the future. Based on everything you know today, given the pressure on business jet, we've had a 777 rate cut announced, do we get somewhere close to that? Or is that out of the question? Just trying to think about modeling Commercial Systems on a go-forward basis.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it is a little early to make that call. We've certainly seen lower Business Aviation production rates than what we anticipated when we put that guidance out. But I'll also say there's been good stuff. We've seen increased rates in air transport. We'
componenttext: Well, it is a little early to make that call. We've certainly seen lower Business Aviation production rates than what we anticipated when we put that guidance out. But I'll also say there's been good stuff. We've seen increased rates in air transport. We've seen increased content on some new aircraft coming into the market. Looks like CSeries is now going to move from the development phase into the production phase. So I don't want to tell you what our rate is right now, because I'm still waiting to see the final detail from my team. But there's been puts and takes. And I think over the long run, they should be able to balance each other out.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Patrick, a follow-up on working capital. You talked about it trending better in the second half of the year. Can you just give a little more detail there, what you're expecting, what we should see from advances and I guess, production inventory? I t
componenttext: Okay. Patrick, a follow-up on working capital. You talked about it trending better in the second half of the year. Can you just give a little more detail there, what you're expecting, what we should see from advances and I guess, production inventory? I think you've already touched on preproduction.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we did see a bit of a buildup in the production inventory, and I would say it was in anticipation of a strong second half for Government Systems in terms of sales. So we did see a buildup in inventory, that was part of the working capital. I expect t
componenttext: Yes, we did see a bit of a buildup in the production inventory, and I would say it was in anticipation of a strong second half for Government Systems in terms of sales. So we did see a buildup in inventory, that was part of the working capital. I expect that to normalize over the course of the balance of the year. And I think the customer payments -- the customer advances, I think we viewed as being a headwind for the year when we came into the year. I think it's probably going to abate a little bit in the second half, but not a lot. I think the improvement you're going to see in working capital is going to be largely the production inventory. Now if I was to point to a risk to our cash flow, it is the fact that we are so back-end loaded on sales that making sure that we get the sales booked and cash collected by the end of the fourth quarter is going to be the challenge that we're all focused on.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ron Epstein with Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is from Ron Epstein with Bank of America.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So big picture question for you, Kelly. One of the themes that seem to emerge at Hamburg this year, even more so than previous years, was the connected airplane and so on and so forth. Can you just wax a little bit on that opportunity for Collins when you
componenttext: So big picture question for you, Kelly. One of the themes that seem to emerge at Hamburg this year, even more so than previous years, was the connected airplane and so on and so forth. Can you just wax a little bit on that opportunity for Collins when you think about high-bandwidth connectivity to the airplane and how ARINC is positioned for that? Because it seems like they're positioned pretty well, but I just wanted to get your take on it.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we are positioned well, and we are -- I mean, we're seeing growth in the connectivity today. We've booked our first 4 customers, 2 in Business Aviation and 2 in the air transport market for Global Express, which is the new you broadband Inmarsat cap
componenttext: Well, we are positioned well, and we are -- I mean, we're seeing growth in the connectivity today. We've booked our first 4 customers, 2 in Business Aviation and 2 in the air transport market for Global Express, which is the new you broadband Inmarsat capability. And we're working a lot of proposals now. We do see this as a big growth opportunity. And recognize, Ron, that today, we really don't provide much cabin-based broadband connectivity in the market. So that's all growth opportunity for us. We're very strong in the flight-deck connectivity, but less so in the cabin. And GX will present a big opportunity for us. And we are also working with OneWeb for a next-generation broadband capability, where we're the exclusive supplier of the radio equipment and then also a value-added reseller. And we're going to bring -- be bringing that on to the airbus platforms in the future. So I'm excited about it. It's happening. There's no question there's going to be strong demand for broadband connectivity. The connectivity solutions that are out there today that aren't broadband just aren't meeting the connected world needs that we all have. And once that happens, it opens the door to applications and services. And we're also focused at providing those kinds of capabilities, where once you have broadband and connectivity, you can move information easier on and off the airplane and provide additional services for either maintenance or operation improvements for the airlines going forward. So it's one of the drivers as to why we think the ARINC acquisition is a great value driver for the long term for our company. And I'm excited about the growth of our Information Management Services portfolio and the opportunities going forward.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe just one natural follow-on, if you can even speculate or maybe even know. What's the required investment to kind of -- to grow in that area? I mean, is it -- how would you quantify that?
componenttext: So maybe just one natural follow-on, if you can even speculate or maybe even know. What's the required investment to kind of -- to grow in that area? I mean, is it -- how would you quantify that?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would put it in -- let me just put it in categories. There's new radios. So you got to develop a radio equipment as compatible with these new broadband satellites. A lot of investment in antenna technology associated with -- again, with the new sa
componenttext: Well, I would put it in -- let me just put it in categories. There's new radios. So you got to develop a radio equipment as compatible with these new broadband satellites. A lot of investment in antenna technology associated with -- again, with the new satellites and being efficient integration, there is new certification cost both in forward fit as well as retrofits. So we have to go get STCs. So for example, for these 4 launch customers that I've talked about, we are investing now in getting the STCs done, getting the certification baseline to retrofit those aircraft. So those are the categories of investment. And they're very similar to what investments we do with other radio systems in the market. So I think we know what those investments are and they're plumbed in our R&D plans as we look forward.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: The next question is from Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to follow up to George's question, that's the biggest decline I think I've ever seen in your margin before are the company under R&D and deferred engineering amortization. To what extent was that also impacted by the fact that it sounds like most of yo
componenttext: So to follow up to George's question, that's the biggest decline I think I've ever seen in your margin before are the company under R&D and deferred engineering amortization. To what extent was that also impacted by the fact that it sounds like most of your commercial revenue gain came in new program 787, A350, CSeries? Is that lower margin business? And then as you look at the second half, I mean, you're going to have higher deferred engineering amortization, higher company-funded R&D, kind of looks to me like the mix continues to shift toward those newer programs. Can the commercial margins improve over this 21% or 22%?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I'd say I think Commercial Systems margin in the back half of the year is going to be pretty close to what it was for the first half of the year. I don't see it changing significantly, Cai. Now I do want to, I guess, clarify couple of points. I
componenttext: Yes, well, I'd say I think Commercial Systems margin in the back half of the year is going to be pretty close to what it was for the first half of the year. I don't see it changing significantly, Cai. Now I do want to, I guess, clarify couple of points. I mean, the margin headwind that we have from this mix shift was significant, and we're talking about from very high-margin product sales to lower-margin customer-funded R&D, and that was a big impact. And I think going forward, we'll still see some of that mix issue, but it won't be quite as dramatic. And I think we feel pretty comfortable that the margin targets that we've laid out for Commercial Systems are achievable.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to add to that, Cai. The margin mix issue is what Patrick said. It's losing the bizjet revenue and increasing the NRE or engineering revenues. It's not a mix of new products coming into market. We have very good profitability with the new products th
componenttext: Just to add to that, Cai. The margin mix issue is what Patrick said. It's losing the bizjet revenue and increasing the NRE or engineering revenues. It's not a mix of new products coming into market. We have very good profitability with the new products that's coming into market. It's part of our common product line strategy where we're reusing. So you shouldn't view 787 anymore as a new product. We've been in rate manufacturing for that one. We're now at 12-month rate, so that's very, very good performance from us. And I'm not worried about new product versus old product mix looking forward.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. But if the commercial -- company R&D is flat year-over-year, deferred engineering is going to be up. You've got to be up 200, 300 basis points in your margin before those items in commercial just to hold relatively flat. So what happens in the seco
componenttext: Right. But if the commercial -- company R&D is flat year-over-year, deferred engineering is going to be up. You've got to be up 200, 300 basis points in your margin before those items in commercial just to hold relatively flat. So what happens in the second half to kind of give you that margin lift, pre those expense items that you're talking about versus the second quarter?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I didn't say it would -- that the company-funded R&D is going to be flat. It's going to be down a little bit. It'll be closer to flat for the third quarter. So that's part of the answer. And then the other answer is continued cost redu
componenttext: Well, first of all, I didn't say it would -- that the company-funded R&D is going to be flat. It's going to be down a little bit. It'll be closer to flat for the third quarter. So that's part of the answer. And then the other answer is continued cost reductions. We're continuing to see benefit from the retirement program flowing through the numbers. If you think about it from an operations perspective, that benefit gets deferred by a quarter because it sits in inventory. So we'll see that benefit flow through as well.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Patrick, maybe just to sort of, hopefully, round that out on the margins. You also mentioned, I think, looking for a sequentially roughly flat total segment margin. Maybe if you could just talk about that by segment, and even if you discuss the progressio
componenttext: Patrick, maybe just to sort of, hopefully, round that out on the margins. You also mentioned, I think, looking for a sequentially roughly flat total segment margin. Maybe if you could just talk about that by segment, and even if you discuss the progression through the end of the year by segment, just given there are a bunch of moving pieces in the commercial segment. It sounds like you gained 200 basis points or so at IMS, which I would assume doesn't repeat and the government growth rate changes a lot. So maybe it would be helpful to just discuss it by segment.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what you're going to see -- you're right, the IMS segment margins were higher than they normally would be. So I think what you'll see is the IMS, I'll say, more normalizing in that 15% to 16% range. I think Commercial Systems, as I mentioned, is g
componenttext: I think what you're going to see -- you're right, the IMS segment margins were higher than they normally would be. So I think what you'll see is the IMS, I'll say, more normalizing in that 15% to 16% range. I think Commercial Systems, as I mentioned, is going to be pretty flat quarter-to-quarter, Q3 and Q4. And what you'll see in Government Systems is that the margin is going to maybe tick up a little bit in the third quarter, not much, and the bulk of the margin expansion is going to be in the fourth quarter.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Sorry, did you say commercial flat 3Q and then flat again 4Q?
componenttext: Okay. Sorry, did you say commercial flat 3Q and then flat again 4Q?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, pretty much.
componenttext: Yes, pretty much.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And how 4Q loaded is the free cash outlook, just given the year-to-date number there and what you said about the collection risks?
componenttext: Okay. And how 4Q loaded is the free cash outlook, just given the year-to-date number there and what you said about the collection risks?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Unfortunately, every year it seems like our cash flow is fourth quarter loaded, and it continues to be. And I'd say, if anything, it'll probably be a little bit more, a little heavier than normal just because of the sales profile we're looking at. So
componenttext: Yes. Unfortunately, every year it seems like our cash flow is fourth quarter loaded, and it continues to be. And I'd say, if anything, it'll probably be a little bit more, a little heavier than normal just because of the sales profile we're looking at. So yes, very heavily weighted toward the fourth quarter.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Richard Safran with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: The next question is from Richard Safran with Buckingham Research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just switch topics here. I was interested in this HMS Manpack contract. Can you tell me some -- a bit of a multipart question. One, you deliver the 30 radios, if full rate production is supposed to commence in '17, does that imply a down select this
componenttext: I'll just switch topics here. I was interested in this HMS Manpack contract. Can you tell me some -- a bit of a multipart question. One, you deliver the 30 radios, if full rate production is supposed to commence in '17, does that imply a down select this year? And to the best you can, if you could discuss your view of the competition and how much of an incremental impact this program could have this fiscal year, assuming a win. And is this a winner-take-all type of thing? Meaning, if you did win, would the $12.7 billion over 10 years all go to Collins?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. A lot of questions there. So let me kind of walk through the program. First of all, we won the initial award with 2 other suppliers. We'll be delivering a roughly 30 radios, I think, into the Army. They'll take those through 2 test regimes, a develo
componenttext: Okay. A lot of questions there. So let me kind of walk through the program. First of all, we won the initial award with 2 other suppliers. We'll be delivering a roughly 30 radios, I think, into the Army. They'll take those through 2 test regimes, a development test regime and a contract test regime, to validate those radios against the overall requirements. So there will be no revenues in fiscal '16 associated with that program because these are free-of-charge radios. We're just providing them to the Army to go through the test. From the results of the test, then they will go to what I would call a call for improvement for the participants who pass the test to then provide an updated price for the next fiscal year buy. So I would say, Richard, it'll probably be this time next year before they make that decision. Their current plan is that they would down select from 3. If there are still 3 viable suppliers through the test phase, they would down select from 3 to 2 for that annual buy. Obviously, if that's this time next year, there's actually very little revenue opportunity next year either because the revenue will go when the radios are delivered. So it really has moved to an '18 -- really, an '18 growth item. The other thing I'll say is that $12.7 billion, while I like the top line numbers, what that is, is that's the max quantities in every case under the IDIQ contract. So think of this contract as a huge matrix with max quantities all priced, and they're all added together. This is not going to be a $12.7 billion contract in my mind. However, it'll be very significant, maybe more like $4 billion to $5 billion of revenue. How much comes to us depends on how many contractors, how much -- what percentage that we win. We've said, hey, look, we can easily see $100 million a year kind of a revenue stream from this program, if not more.

componenttext: Yes, absolutely, and that will come to us in a couple of different ways. It depends on where the intellectual property resides. We'll be able to do that for the things that we have the intellectual property. We'll be a -- think of us as a data delivery source to other companies who own the intellectual property going forward. So there's great opportunities. We'll be able to put apps in the -- in our aircraft and the ground. We'll be able to drive services and support that, again, to the OEMs, to the product OEMs as well as the airlines.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Rockwell Collins Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.For opening remarks and management introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Rockwell Collins' Vice Pres
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Rockwell Collins Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.
For opening remarks and management introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Rockwell Collins' Vice President of Investor Relations, Ryan Miller. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning to all of you on the call. With me on the line this morning are Rockwell Collins' Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Kelly Ortberg; and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Patrick Allen.Tod
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning to all of you on the call. With me on the line this morning are Rockwell Collins' Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Kelly Ortberg; and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Patrick Allen.
Today's call is being webcast, and you can view the slides we'll be presenting today at our website at www.rockwellcollins.com under the Investor Relations tab. These slides include certain non-GAAP financial information and a reconciliation to the related GAAP measure.
Please note, today's presentation and webcast will include certain projections and statements that are forward looking. Actual results may differ materially from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including those detailed on Slide 2 of this webcast presentation and from time to time in the company's Securities and Exchange Commission filings. These forward-looking statements are made as of today, and the company assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements.
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Kelly.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Ryan, and good morning, everyone. This was really a solid quarter for us as we saw some major accomplishments in our markets and also had good execution performance in all of our businesses. Among the market highlights was the C-Series ent
componenttext:
Well, thanks, Ryan, and good morning, everyone. This was really a solid quarter for us as we saw some major accomplishments in our markets and also had good execution performance in all of our businesses. 
Among the market highlights was the C-Series entry in the service with Swiss Air. We're very pleased to see Bombardier accomplish this major milestone and it's a real sign that this program is turning the quarter. As you know, this has been a big investment for us, and we're all pleased to be moving from the investment phase to the return phase for this program. 
Another major OEM accomplishment was the successful refueling test with the KC-46 tanker, paving the way towards production of that airplane. These are both important programs for our long-term growth in our commercial and government businesses. Annually, both Boeing and Airbus survey the airlines to gauge their supplier performance and customer support. And recently, it was announced that Rockwell Collins was ranked #1 for both Airbus and Boeing. In fact, we are ranked ahead both of the OEMs themselves. I'm very proud of our team's performance, which is a testament to our brand promise in building trust every day and will help us to continue to be the supplier of choice in our markets. 
Overall, we executed our business quite well during the quarter, delivering solid margin performance while also stepping up our R&D spending in Commercial Systems to support the development of the 777X. We also made great progress in booking the government orders necessary to achieve our abnormally large second half sales plan. And our IMS business grew 10%, and we achieved our expected growth in the non-aviation segment, which demonstrates that some of our strategies to grow that portion of our business are beginning to take traction. 
Now we're not without challenges, and they seemed to be focused in our Commercial Systems markets right now. The Business Aviation and market continues to struggle to find the bottom. This last quarter, we saw shaky utilization and recently, we've seen even further declines in demand from the OEMs. If you recall, we started the year with some discount in OEM production. And we saw reduced at the beginning of the calendar year, which used up our discount and then some. I was hoping to see demand stabilize through the summer, but unfortunately, this hasn't been the case. This is going to further impact our top line in Commercial Systems. Just to give you some color on this. It's not really specific to any particular airplane type, but rather an overall market condition.
We're seeing softness in product demand across all major business jet manufacturers. Recall that we moved our fiscal 2016 guidance back to the fourth quarter earnings call to allow us to get better aligned with the OEMs, and I think this is going to be really applicable to bizjet demand this year. It's not yet clear to us how these latest changes from the OEMs will impact their 2017 demand. And I'm that they're going to be monitoring the next quarter of market dynamics before they set that outlook.
In addition, we've had another quarter of no growth in air transport MRO. And in the last earnings call, I indicated that I believe this is a structural change to our aftermarket due to the component recycling practices at the airlines. So if you couple the Business Aviation OEM and the air transport aftermarket sales environments, we're lowering our Commercial Systems sales forecast for the year from up single-digits to down about 1%. 
On a more positive note, as I mentioned earlier, Government Systems had a nice quarter in sales and earnings, but has an even bigger fourth quarter yet to go. And as I've done in the last couple of calls, I'd like to give you some granularity on how we're progressing in capturing the business to achieve that growth. 
During the last quarterly call, I said that 77% of the second half growth was either in backlog or coming from annual follow-on buys. This is now at 94% at the end of the third quarter. So I remain very confident in our ability to achieve the sales growth that we projected and finished the year strong.
Some of these sales will be later in the year than we originally planned and it's going to stress our ability to collect cash by year-end, and that's a contributor to us adjusting our guidance on cash flow to lower end of our previous range. 
So to summarize before Patrick takes you through the details of the quarter, we really executed well this past quarter. I'm particularly pleased to see the restructuring savings flowing as we expected. And we are successfully bringing in the government business need to accomplish the abnormally large second half ramp. Business Aviation remains a challenge for us as the industry is still searching for the bottom of the market. And I continue to see good things from our IMS business, and we're making good progress on the new OEM programs that will set us up for future growth. 
So with that, let me turn the call over to Patrick to walk us through the quarterly details.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kelly, and morning to everyone as well. I'd now like to walk you to today's presentation slide that summarize our results for the third quarter of fiscal year 2016. I'll begin on Slide 3, where we highlight our total company third quarter sales, e
componenttext:
Thanks, Kelly, and morning to everyone as well. I'd now like to walk you to today's presentation slide that summarize our results for the third quarter of fiscal year 2016. I'll begin on Slide 3, where we highlight our total company third quarter sales, earnings per share, income from continuing operations and shares outstanding. 
Total company sales for the quarter increased $41 million or 3% compared to the third quarter of last year, primarily due to higher Government Systems and Information Management Services sales. Income from continuing operations increased $36 million or 20%, and earnings per share from continuing operations increased $0.30 or 23% compared to the same period last year. The increase in income and earnings per share from continuing operations was primarily due to lower income tax expense that was favorably impacted by the release of the valuation allowance related to a capital loss carryforward, as well as higher pretax earnings from the higher sales.
As we turn to Slide 4, Commercial Systems achieved revenue of $612 million in the quarter, about flat with the same period last year. Sales related to aircraft OEMs decreased $6 million or 2% to $367 million, primarily due to lower business jet aircraft OEM production rates, lower product deliveries to a Chinese regional jet manufacturer and lower Airbus A330 production rates. This was mostly offset by higher deliveries that support the A350 and 787 production rate ramps, favorable customer timing for airline selectable equipment, higher Bombardier C-Series sales in support of its entry into service this year and higher customer-funded development program revenues. Aftermarket sales increased $11 million or 5%, due to higher simulation of deliveries, inorganic sales from the acquisition of International Communications Group and higher flight deck retrofits, partially offset by lower Spira provisioning and lower capital retrofits.
On Commercial Systems, operating earnings were flat at $141 million and operating earnings were about flat at 23%. Operating earnings and margins were flat with the prior year, as benefits from the cost savings initiatives from previously announced restructuring plans were offset by unfavorable sales mix as lower margin customer-funded development sales increased and higher-margin business jet OEM sales decreased.
Moving on to Slide 5. Government Systems overall revenue increased by 5% to $555 million driven by higher fix wing platform revenues and higher simulation training sales, partially offset by lower deliveries of various's rotary wing platforms, the wind down of an international electronic warfare program and lower international deliveries of targeting systems. 
Government Systems third quarter operating earnings increased $7 million to $115 million, resulting in an operating margin of 20.7%, a 30 basis point improvement compared to the third quarter of the prior year. The increased operating earnings resulted from the higher sales volume and cost savings initiatives from previously announced restructuring plans, partially offset by unfavorable development program adjustments.
Turning to Slide 6. Information Management Services sales increased 10% over the prior year, as commercial and Business Aviation services sales increased 9%, while the non-aviation related businesses increased 11%, primarily due to higher airport and rail program sales. Information management services third quarter operating earnings increased $3 million to $26 million, resulting in operating margin of 15.6% compared to 15.1% in the third quarter of the last year. The increase in operating earnings and margin was due to the incremental earnings of the higher sales volume.
Looking next to Slide 7. We show year-to-date results for revenue, income from continuing operations, earnings per share and operating cash flow. Through the third quarter, we generated $223 million of operating cash flow compared to $341 million last year. The decrease in cash generation resulted primarily from the timing of sales and lower advanced payments from our customers. These items were partially offset by lower tax payments.
Slide 8 provides an update to our total R&D investment. Total spend decreased from $731 million in the first 9 months of fiscal 2015 to $741 million year-to-date in fiscal 2016. Company funded R&D decreased $47 million due to lower business jet development cost in Commercial Systems and lower Software Defined Radio development costs in Government Systems. Customer-funded research and development expense increased $25 million due to higher development costs for international regional jet development programs in Commercial Systems, partially offset by the wind down of an international electronic warfare program in Government Systems. Preproduction engineering investment net increased due to higher costs incurred for certain military transport programs in Government Systems and the Global 7000, 8000 program, partially offset by lower spend on the C-Series program.
Moving to Slide 9. We show the status of our capital structure as of the end of the third quarter compared to the end of last year. During the first 9 months of fiscal 2016, our debt-to-EBITDA ratio increased to 2 from 1.7 at year-end. The increase is primarily due to an increase in commercial paper as the first 3 quarters of the year had typically light cash flows. I expect the level of debt to come down over the balance of the year as a larger portion of our cash flow is traditionally generated later in the year and we pay down a portion of that short-term debt.
The updated status of the share repurchase program as of the end of the quarter is detailed on Slide 10. During the third quarter, we repurchased 0.7 million shares at an average cost of $90.71. Our repurchase authority remaining at the end of the quarter was $125 million.
Now to move to Slide 11, where we provide a summary of our fiscal 2016 financial guidance, which has been updated as we enter the last fiscal quarter of the year. Total sales are now expected to be about $5.3 billion, which is the bottom of the previously guided range of $5.3 billion to $5.4 billion. As Kelly discussed in his opening remarks, we have updated Commercial Systems sales to be down about percentage point this year due to softness in business jet OEM deliveries, as well as muted market conditions in air transport service and support. We have narrowed the earnings per share guidance to 5 50 to 5 55, which is within the previously guided range of 5 45 to 5 65.
We have also updated our cash flow from operations outlook to be about $750 million, which is the bottom of the previously guided range, due primarily to the timing of receivable collections and higher preproduction engineering spend. Our guidance for total segment operating margins, research and development of investment and capital expenditures is unchanged from the previous guidance. 
With that, that's the end of my review of the financial results and projection. So Ryan, back to you to kick off the Q&A session.

componenttext: Well, let me answer the last part first. So we primarily do cabin equipment for to so, so it's now -- those aren't superheavy content aircraft for us, but we are exposed to that. We're seeing it really across all categories of aircraft. As I said in the comments. It really -- I can't point right now to -- this is a heavy phenomena and/or a median or a light phenomenon. It's really across the board. I think everybody has gotten through another quarter. It's not been an overly good quarter in terms of the end markets, and I think anybody's true enough their outlook for the balance of the year. As I mentioned, I have hoped that we get through the summer. But we were clear to point out that the summer time, returning unadjusted rates, we're probably going to your about it. And unfortunately, we had been hearing about it from all of them.

componenttext: Well, it's a good question, Sam. But I think there may build a little bit of opportunity in our CapEx number. We typically, if you go -- you have to go back a couple of years. But if you go back a couple of years, we typically been a little bit more back-end loaded on our CapEx. I don't think that's been through over the last couple of years. But typically, it has been back-end loaded. But is there a little bit of opportunity in CapEx? I think there might be.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Carter, I can't see any conditions at this point that say, "Hey, that's it. We're at the bottom." The market continues to struggle. What I said in my opening remarks was it's not clear to us yet how these adjustments that we just recently received a
componenttext: Well, Carter, I can't see any conditions at this point that say, "Hey, that's it. We're at the bottom." The market continues to struggle. What I said in my opening remarks was it's not clear to us yet how these adjustments that we just recently received are going to impact their long-term or particularly,their '17 production rates. My assumption sitting here today would be, half we don't see some sort of a market improvement that these adjustments are going to set the go in production rates going into next year. Hopefully, that'll at least give us a stable base going forward unless the market conditions continue to erode.

componenttext: Yes, we're, as Pat said, we're in the middle of putting together our '17 plan right now. I think we're going to be pretty conservative in our outlook, which I thought we were coming into this fiscal year. We put the discount there it turned out even in that was to even optimistic. So yes, we're all looking for the bottom. I think when you're looking for the bottom, you're going to tend to plan pretty conservatively and hope for upside.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Gursky with Citi.
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, I was wondering if you could just spend a few minutes and talk a little bit about your mid to longer-term revenue and earnings goals in the context of all the puts and takes that you're seeing. Maybe highlight for us your thoughts here on this call
componenttext: Kelly, I was wondering if you could just spend a few minutes and talk a little bit about your mid to longer-term revenue and earnings goals in the context of all the puts and takes that you're seeing. Maybe highlight for us your thoughts here on this call about some of the downside risks. But maybe provide a little bit on the update on the key drivers for growth that may allow us to get to that mid to long-term growth targets that you've got for both revenue and earnings.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think, first of all, the linearity of that long-term outlook certainly hasn't been what we expected. And there have been puts and takes, both positive and negative. I think we're in the short term, dealing with a lot of the negative, which is dela
componenttext: Sure. I think, first of all, the linearity of that long-term outlook certainly hasn't been what we expected. And there have been puts and takes, both positive and negative. I think we're in the short term, dealing with a lot of the negative, which is delays in entry in the service of programs, lower aftermarket MRO component than we originally expected and a much, much weaker Business Aviation demand than we anticipated. On the positive side, we gained additional share on the 777X. We've seen increases in production rates in there about a the aircraft, significant increases in production rates on narrow-body aircraft. Of course, we've got the new, a lot of new positions with the Mac's and the 777X are petting in. That's not necessarily new, but continue to be growth drivers for us. And then we planned our defense business at that time at a sequester level. And currently, the budget environment is clearly better than that. So our ability to grow from -- for our government business is certainly a little bit better. I think the -- as I look at that outlook and how we're doing against it, obviously, '16, we're not achieving that top level numbers. '17, I think we're going to take a hard look at Business Aviation. It's the wildcard for us. If we can just get that business to stabilize, I think we can grow the company. If you put that in perspective, Business Aviation OEM is about 20% to 25% of our commercial revenues are about 10% of that company revenues. And so when we can get to flat, we can grow the company. The challenge is quarters like this one, where we've got 22% decline in Business Aviation, is offsetting a lot of really good growth for us. And the information management business, I think continues to track pretty well to our original plan.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: The next question is from Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a 2-part question on business jets. First, all of the manufacturers reporting have cited pricing has been particularly weak because of the erosion in the preowned market. Are you seeing any negative pricing pressures? And secondly, usually, when OE
componenttext: I have a 2-part question on business jets. First, all of the manufacturers reporting have cited pricing has been particularly weak because of the erosion in the preowned market. Are you seeing any negative pricing pressures? And secondly, usually, when OEM's off and prices preowned come down, you start to see a pickup in preowned sales that tends to bolster the aftermarket. Are you seeing any positive signs or potential positive signs in bizjet aftermarket?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the bizjet aftermarket has been pretty good for us for the whole year. We continue to see good retrofit activity in Avionics, which I do view as a positive sign. Last year, it was probably more focused on cabin upgrade, then nobody was updating the
componenttext: Well, the bizjet aftermarket has been pretty good for us for the whole year. We continue to see good retrofit activity in Avionics, which I do view as a positive sign. Last year, it was probably more focused on cabin upgrade, then nobody was updating the front end of the airplane. But now we're seeing that, and that's continued through this quarter. Regarding pricing pressure, I think our near-term pricing is pretty fixed relative to the market. So I think the OEMs have to deal with that. they're certainly turning around and looking to the supply chain to help them in any way, but that's not unique to the Business Aviation market.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Seth Seifman with Jeffrey Morgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Seth Seifman with Jeffrey Morgan.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could talk a little bit more about the air transport aftermarket. What happened at Intertrade in the quarter? And also, what the contribution was from the acquisitions that you did in 2015? Just to get a sense of kind of where the organic
componenttext: I wonder if you could talk a little bit more about the air transport aftermarket. What happened at Intertrade in the quarter? And also, what the contribution was from the acquisitions that you did in 2015? Just to get a sense of kind of where the organic business is. It seems you faced some pressure here before and we talked about some of the causes, but it seems to be gathering some strength. And just kind of wondering if you have any insight into why that's the case.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look at the -- if you peel the onion way back, I'd say in air transport, our MRO, just core MRO, not used components, was down low single-digit. And that was offset by some Intertrade growth for the quarter. As far as the inorganic growth that
componenttext: Yes, if you look at the -- if you peel the onion way back, I'd say in air transport, our MRO, just core MRO, not used components, was down low single-digit. And that was offset by some Intertrade growth for the quarter. As far as the inorganic growth that's primarily coming out of our ICG acquisition, which is the satellite-based communications equipment, I think about $4 million of ICG growth was in the air transport and another couple of million was in BizAv.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just do you get a sense that the pressure, the structural pressure that you've talked about in the commercial air transport aftermarket has been gathering steam just because it seems like retirements has been moderating and traffic growth
componenttext: Okay, great. And just do you get a sense that the pressure, the structural pressure that you've talked about in the commercial air transport aftermarket has been gathering steam just because it seems like retirements has been moderating and traffic growth has been fairly solid, but it does seem like these headwinds have been increasing.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think they have. Certainly, for our portfolio, if you look at our installed base, it's heavily a leverage on 75, 76 and 747 400. And while we have seen retirements abate a bit, it's been propped more in the narrowbodies, which is not a significant
componenttext: Yes, I think they have. Certainly, for our portfolio, if you look at our installed base, it's heavily a leverage on 75, 76 and 747 400. And while we have seen retirements abate a bit, it's been propped more in the narrowbodies, which is not a significant of an installed base today for us because we don't have flight decks in the narrowbodies. So our portfolio is feeling probably a little bit more the impact of recycling. And that's coming in 2 ways. We don't get the repair action through our service center. But also, we're seeing lower what I'll call legacy spares, where someone is just buying our legacy product because they're able to fill that spare with the used component.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from George Shapiro with Shapiro research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

componenttext: I just want to pursue a little bit more of the business jet market because while Bombardier and Embraer deliveries are down, Cessna actually has quite a decent increase in air deliveries in the second quarter. So some of your comments related to the fact that on the new Cessna products, you don't have the market share that you used to have.

componenttext: Yes, I think at Cessna, you do you have to go look at the mix. I think we have a mix. I think they were -- Can Air deliveries reported down quite a bit and, of course, we have the Can Air position and we don't on some of the new growth platforms down there. So I do think that's a little bit of a mix issue at Cessna.

componenttext: I had a question and clarification. Pat, the clarification on the cash flows. Is there any component of that, that is on the commercial side maybe in terms of receivables from some of your OEM customers in terms of timing on their payables? And then, Kelly, on the cabin retrofit and some of the weakness there, could you speak -- talk to that a little bit? Where are you seeing that and what's the dynamic behind that?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me answer the first part of your question, Rob. I think it is fair to say that we always have puts and takes with respect to cash flow timing, particularly at year-end because a day or 2 can mean quite a bit in terms of our cash flow. So that's always
componenttext: Let me answer the first part of your question, Rob. I think it is fair to say that we always have puts and takes with respect to cash flow timing, particularly at year-end because a day or 2 can mean quite a bit in terms of our cash flow. So that's always a risk and an opportunity. I wouldn't say that we have anything specifically baked in with respect to commercial OEM, I'll say, paying behavior. So we'll continue to monitor it. But no, there's nothing specific the commercial payment practices.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Patrick, no one has made an effort to change payable terms?
componenttext: Patrick, no one has made an effort to change payable terms?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I didn't say that. I think we have a couple of our larger customers have been -- are very active in terms of talking to us about cash flow payment terms, and we're going to continue to negotiate that. But I would tell you that we're still working it.
componenttext: I didn't say that. I think we have a couple of our larger customers have been -- are very active in terms of talking to us about cash flow payment terms, and we're going to continue to negotiate that. But I would tell you that we're still working it.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, Boeing, we do not have a Boeing replan in terms of their payment strategy in our full year outlook. That's not in accordance with our contracts that we have with them. So we're expecting them to withhold that. I will say quarter to date, Boeing is d
componenttext: Look, Boeing, we do not have a Boeing replan in terms of their payment strategy in our full year outlook. That's not in accordance with our contracts that we have with them. So we're expecting them to withhold that. I will say quarter to date, Boeing is delinquent and Boeing has contributed to some of our underperformance here this quarter in cash flow, which is disappointing, but we're working that with them.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on the retrofit?
componenttext: Okay. And on the retrofit?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rob, on the retrofit, I don't know whether I can point to anything market wise. It's truly is we're just seeing when airplanes are coming in for engine mods or maintenance actions, that were sailing more avionics and less cabin. It appears to be that
componenttext: Yes, Rob, on the retrofit, I don't know whether I can point to anything market wise. It's truly is we're just seeing when airplanes are coming in for engine mods or maintenance actions, that were sailing more avionics and less cabin. It appears to be that kind of have a fixed amount of money and the money shifting a little bit towards the avionics upgrades. I don't know if that's because they think they need those avionics upgrades to sell the airplane. Some of them are mandated kind of things and they're just analyst go ahead and do them right now might be indicative of them keeping the aircraft longer. Now cabin upgrades haven't gone away. They were just particularly strong last quarter, and they're not as strong here through this year.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Howard Rubel with Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from Howard Rubel with Jefferies.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to shift a little bit towards some new products, Kelly. 2 things, one is you highlighted the simulator business and demand. Is there something that's changed permanently, I mean, given the pilot shortage? And then just very briefly touch on, you ha
componenttext: I want to shift a little bit towards some new products, Kelly. 2 things, one is you highlighted the simulator business and demand. Is there something that's changed permanently, I mean, given the pilot shortage? And then just very briefly touch on, you have 7 3 MACs, you have CSeries and A350 all ramping fairly substantially next year. Could you elaborate a little bit on the trajectory?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look at the ramp-ups next year, you're right on the ramps. If you look at 737 Mac's, that's going to feather in over probably about 3-year timeframe as they transition from NG to Mac's. At Boeing next year, while I'm not -- I don't have a plan
componenttext: Yes, if you look at the ramp-ups next year, you're right on the ramps. If you look at 737 Mac's, that's going to feather in over probably about 3-year timeframe as they transition from NG to Mac's. At Boeing next year, while I'm not -- I don't have a plan yet that I'm sitting in front of. I would expect that we'll see the Mac's tailwind be offset by declines in the 777 and the 747-8. So we'll tend to mid-themselves in fiscal '17, but then we'll see the incremental growth in '18 and '19 as we continue to feather in the MACs. I think we're all watching airbuses ramp up on A350. Right now, we're pretty well aligned with their public guidance there. But I think everybody is watching to see if they're going to be able to achieve that going forward. So hopefully, we'll get some more clarity before we have to provide any guidance on '17.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as it relates to the simulator products, I would say those products tend to be a little bit lumpy just in terms of the timing of deliveries. I wouldn't read it in terms of permanent change to the trajectory of that business. It's still a range to be p
componenttext: And as it relates to the simulator products, I would say those products tend to be a little bit lumpy just in terms of the timing of deliveries. I wouldn't read it in terms of permanent change to the trajectory of that business. It's still a range to be pretty good business. We still anticipate good growth in that business, but I think it was a little bit unusual this quarter.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there's no share gain or anything else that you can point to, Patrick?
componenttext: So there's no share gain or anything else that you can point to, Patrick?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think there are probably a fair amount of deliveries aross the board. Actually, there are a lot of deliveries in the commercial side of business for some similar products. I don't think there were a lot of share gain, though.
componenttext: No, I think there are probably a fair amount of deliveries aross the board. Actually, there are a lot of deliveries in the commercial side of business for some similar products. I don't think there were a lot of share gain, though.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Ken Herbert with Canaccord.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

componenttext: Just wanted to shift gears again to the Government Systems. You had good growth in the quarter and I know it's consistent with what you've been talking about, and it sounds like the full year outlook remains on track. Can you specifically 2 parts, specifically highlight any more detail on specific programs you saw ramping this quarter or any other color on the specific strength there? And then second, can you provide an update on the Manpack opportunity? I know the radios are going tested now and any further detail on when you're looking for the potential down select there and any update on the testing process?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me hit Manpack. First of all, yes, we've delivered the units, as have competitors and they're in the test process. I'm probably not going to be providing you much detailed information as highly competitive between now and the down selection. S
componenttext: Yes, so let me hit Manpack. First of all, yes, we've delivered the units, as have competitors and they're in the test process. I'm probably not going to be providing you much detailed information as highly competitive between now and the down selection. So I'm not going to be speaking too much anymore about what's going on relative to Manpack. We do expect the down select to be towards the end of the second quarter or early third quarter of next fiscal year. As far as government programs, if you look in the third quarter, we saw some pretty good growth in military simulation and training. Our E6 program had some good growth and international PIII is also. We saw continued decline year-on-year in rotary wing, primarily driven by the oil and gas challenges that we've been dealing with. If you look towards the fourth quarter, I think you're going to see pretty good growth across our entire government portfolio. And in fact, I think our come that portfolio probably exceed our avionics portfolio in terms of overall growth, where key programs there are, our international C-130s. We've done a good job of booking those. You may have seen a press release where we won a Black Hawk simulator program down in Mexico. That was one of those that we had planned to win and convert in the year. We've got growth in F35, continued growth in E6, and then some simulation and training products that we're expecting to grow. So again, a pretty big fourth quarter, abnormally big fourth quarter for us in our government portfolio, but pretty much the majority of that is booked and now executing. And I expect that we'll have a really bang up quarter here for our government business, which is good. This is the first -- this Q3 was the first quarter of growth in quite a few quarters here for our government business. So it's good to get that finally turning in the right direction.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
