componenttext: The next question is from David Strauss of UBS.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, want to see if you could touch on this trajectory of company funded R&D as we head into '17. I think you had -- you spoken previously about '17 looking a lot more like fiscal '15 rather than '16 in terms of company funded R&D. If you could touch on
componenttext: Kelly, want to see if you could touch on this trajectory of company funded R&D as we head into '17. I think you had -- you spoken previously about '17 looking a lot more like fiscal '15 rather than '16 in terms of company funded R&D. If you could touch on that. And then also touch on, assuming that on the company funded side along with the increase in preproduction amortization might looks like it's going to be tougher commercial systems EBIT to grow even if you were to assume that business jet was flat in '17. If you could just touch on that.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the first half of this year has been a low half in terms of Commercial Systems, company funded R&D. And you're seeing us ramp that up here in the third quarter. You'll see additional ramp-up in the fourth quarter. So I think while again, I don't h
componenttext: Yes. So the first half of this year has been a low half in terms of Commercial Systems, company funded R&D. And you're seeing us ramp that up here in the third quarter. You'll see additional ramp-up in the fourth quarter. So I think while again, I don't have '17's detailed plan, I think '17, you can expect us to be spending kind of more at the rate at which we're ramping to right now. Obviously, the more expense R&D that we spend on the year, the more challenge that places on our government revenues. I wouldn't say that's necessarily, I'm sorry, a commercial margin. I wouldn't necessarily say that's new. We've always known that we were going to be ramping back up the R&D and we've got to go drive the good news out of the product profitability in order to offset that R&D ramp.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Michael Ciarmoli with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Michael Ciarmoli with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, maybe if we could just go back to the Government Systems. You were hitting on it. Best quarter of growth, I think, since fiscal '11. Fourth quarter looks to be strong. You've got some easy comps in the first half. I mean, are we out of the woods he
componenttext: Kelly, maybe if we could just go back to the Government Systems. You were hitting on it. Best quarter of growth, I think, since fiscal '11. Fourth quarter looks to be strong. You've got some easy comps in the first half. I mean, are we out of the woods here based on current visibility, what you're seeing in the pipeline programs? I mean, can we expect Government Systems to start putting up consistent year-over-year growth at this point? Or from your perspective, is it too early to call?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you can start to see that we're going to have consistent year-on-year growth coming out of our government portfolio. Now this year is strange because we had the first half, second half. I don't think you should assume that we're going to conti
componenttext: No, I think you can start to see that we're going to have consistent year-on-year growth coming out of our government portfolio. Now this year is strange because we had the first half, second half. I don't think you should assume that we're going to continue to grow at the second half right. But what we've said was to get flat in '15, low single-digit growth coming out. And I think the budget environment is going to allow us over the next couple of years to move that growth rate to low to mid single-digit growth out of our government portfolio, which is upside from our long-term outlook, as I've talked about before.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just, if I may, are there headwinds out there? And I think about maybe the Brazilian economy, the KC-390 deal, there are the specific programs you might be more worried about creating some unforeseen headwinds in government?
componenttext: Got it. And just, if I may, are there headwinds out there? And I think about maybe the Brazilian economy, the KC-390 deal, there are the specific programs you might be more worried about creating some unforeseen headwinds in government?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that KC-390 is going to go through some challenging times going forward. I think that we've got that baked into our overall outlook. I think oil and gas continues to be a question mark for Siebel Halo. But the areas where we're expecting gro
componenttext: Well, I think that KC-390 is going to go through some challenging times going forward. I think that we've got that baked into our overall outlook. I think oil and gas continues to be a question mark for Siebel Halo. But the areas where we're expecting growth, I think that's why I highlighted KC-46, really important growth program for us at 35, appears very solid. And that's a good growth program for us. And then back to the comment on the Manpack program, that's an important program that will start driving growth here probably towards the end of next year and into the following year. So we've got the programs and opportunities ahead of us to have this business on a continuous growth trajectory.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Richard Safran with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: The next question is from Richard Safran with Buckingham Research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to ask you about mandates. If I miss your comments about this, if you made it before, I apologize. I know that MRO activities in generally big revenue driver for you, but I believe it could drive Coptic mandates. So I wanted to get a sense fro
componenttext: So I wanted to ask you about mandates. If I miss your comments about this, if you made it before, I apologize. I know that MRO activities in generally big revenue driver for you, but I believe it could drive Coptic mandates. So I wanted to get a sense from you how things like D checks are trending? Are you seeing more D check schedules if you're expecting more mandate activity in the future. How things are looking there?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I probably can't comment as I look at specifically on D check's schedule. The only thing I can say is that we -- for mandates, we do typically, especially for the large fleet operators, they try to get those mandates incorporated into their scheduled main
componenttext: I probably can't comment as I look at specifically on D check's schedule. The only thing I can say is that we -- for mandates, we do typically, especially for the large fleet operators, they try to get those mandates incorporated into their scheduled maintenance outlook. And we saw that with the TCAS changes here in the past 2 years. We've got the ADS-B mandate mostly ahead of us. We're actually expecting some initial revenues in both our transporting government bizjets out of ADS-B here in the fourth quarter. So that's just picking up. But again, these are mandated with a particular time. So if they don't get them done during their normal scheduled maintenance, then they affectedly have taken their planes down to do the mods. And unfortunately, we do see a lot of people wait until the very end and a very opportunity at the very before the mandate effectivity date hits.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about commercial margins on a pre-R&D basis. I guess, I think you've cited mix as the key driver of the year-to-date compression. And I guess you've pointed to that being business jet driven, I guess, also, the customer-funded development
componenttext: I wanted to ask about commercial margins on a pre-R&D basis. I guess, I think you've cited mix as the key driver of the year-to-date compression. And I guess you've pointed to that being business jet driven, I guess, also, the customer-funded development sales. But could you talk about how much different the business jet margins are versus the rest of original equipment and versus aftermarket in the commercial business?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I think what we're trying to describe in terms of the year-over-year headwind on margins due to the mix is the bizjet OE compared to customer funded and RA. So we're really getting -- we're staying flat. We're trading some pretty high-margin bizj
componenttext: Yes. No, I think what we're trying to describe in terms of the year-over-year headwind on margins due to the mix is the bizjet OE compared to customer funded and RA. So we're really getting -- we're staying flat. We're trading some pretty high-margin bizjet OE for low to no margin customer funded engineering. That's the big mix change. Now as it relates to bizjet OE compared to the entire commercial portfolio, I'd tell you it's among the more profitable business we have. I think it's probably -- we've always said bizjet, their margins are hard in air transport margins. Aftermarket tends to be a little bit higher than only. But I think the bizjet OE tends to be a pretty good margin product for us.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So business jet always higher than aftermarket on average?
componenttext: So business jet always higher than aftermarket on average?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I'd say bizjet is probably on par with it. I just want to clarify. The real impact, though, is the fact that we've got low to no margin customer funded NRE to the portfolio.
componenttext: No, I'd say bizjet is probably on par with it. I just want to clarify. The real impact, though, is the fact that we've got low to no margin customer funded NRE to the portfolio.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what's the net mix impact '17 versus '16 pre-R&D?
componenttext: So what's the net mix impact '17 versus '16 pre-R&D?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the net mix impact should actually pre-R&D should be good because I think we're going to see customer funded NRE coming down and we'll see some product sales coming up. So the pre-R&D impact is going to be good. The issue then is, okay, what happens
componenttext: Well, the net mix impact should actually pre-R&D should be good because I think we're going to see customer funded NRE coming down and we'll see some product sales coming up. So the pre-R&D impact is going to be good. The issue then is, okay, what happens in customer funded, our company funded R&D, and is Kelly has already referred to it. That may tick up. Pre-R&D margin should benefit from mix.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up some on the cash flow, Patrick. I mean, receivables year-to-date are up about 160, net in the quarter is up 160 and customer advances down 100. And you mentioned that you're waiting for a Boeing payment. I don't know whether you
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up some on the cash flow, Patrick. I mean, receivables year-to-date are up about 160, net in the quarter is up 160 and customer advances down 100. And you mentioned that you're waiting for a Boeing payment. I don't know whether you would quantify how much that is and whether that's related to some contract you haven't signed with them yet or what it was. But the bottom line to me when you add all this together, you need like over $500 million cash flow in the fourth quarter to get to the low end of your guidance. And I'm just trying to put some pieces together as to how you might get there.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you've touched on a few of them anyway, George. As it relates to Boeing, we got probably between $30 million and $40 million of receivables that we are rating collection on Boeing. And it's not really contractual issue. It's just they haven't
componenttext: Yes, I think you've touched on a few of them anyway, George. As it relates to Boeing, we got probably between $30 million and $40 million of receivables that we are rating collection on Boeing. And it's not really contractual issue. It's just they haven't paid us. So that's out there. We do need to collect that. We have a very large ramp on Government Systems revenue side. So you said receivables have -- had spiked up, absolutely have. Getting those billed and collected, the ones that exist as of June 30, it's important. And also the ramp into the fourth quarter and getting that ramp accomplished early billed and collected. I think those are the sort of the keys to getting that cash flow number. We've always had back-end loaded cash flow. But kind of like the government system sales this year is even more back-end loaded than it has been in the past.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's why of service. I mean, you always had a strong cash flow before, Q4, [ph] just much stronger this year.
componenttext: That's why of service. I mean, you always had a strong cash flow before, Q4, [ph] just much stronger this year.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, and I think you've touched on a number of the key drivers to getting that cash flow in the fourth quarter.
componenttext: Yes. Yes, and I think you've touched on a number of the key drivers to getting that cash flow in the fourth quarter.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Peter Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, I had a question on commercially rotorcraft. Can you size that unit for us and maybe give us some color on, I'm just guessing is probably down double digits this year in government just given the market, and I'm wondering if you're seeing that bein
componenttext: Kelly, I had a question on commercially rotorcraft. Can you size that unit for us and maybe give us some color on, I'm just guessing is probably down double digits this year in government just given the market, and I'm wondering if you're seeing that being another headwind into '17.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so -- again, the commercially rotorcraft is booked in our government portfolio, and it's not all of the commercial rotorcraft that we're seeing being impaired right now. It's the aircraft that are supporting the oil and gas component in the market.
componenttext: Well, so -- again, the commercially rotorcraft is booked in our government portfolio, and it's not all of the commercial rotorcraft that we're seeing being impaired right now. It's the aircraft that are supporting the oil and gas component in the market. Pat, do you have?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we typically says about 15% of our portfolio in Government Systems is helicopters. About 1/3 of that is commercial helicopters. And as Kelly mentioned, some of that civil kind of para military here some of it is oil and gas, probably about half and h
componenttext: Yes, we typically says about 15% of our portfolio in Government Systems is helicopters. About 1/3 of that is commercial helicopters. And as Kelly mentioned, some of that civil kind of para military here some of it is oil and gas, probably about half and half maybe. So I think this give you a size as to what the impact with the oil and gas piece is.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one last follow-up. On your strategy to be more service oriented in terms of the non-aviation businesses, the IMS, can you give us some color there maybe in terms how far along you are with that and how much traction you can get there, do you thi
componenttext: And just one last follow-up. On your strategy to be more service oriented in terms of the non-aviation businesses, the IMS, can you give us some color there maybe in terms how far along you are with that and how much traction you can get there, do you think?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, probably, the first area that we're making progress in that is in the rail business, where we are providing positive train controls, software as a service. We've got that now into the market and we're starting to transition. This isn't going to be a
componenttext: Yes, probably, the first area that we're making progress in that is in the rail business, where we are providing positive train controls, software as a service. We've got that now into the market and we're starting to transition. This isn't going to be a switch to where one day, we just flip over and then we move from project to subscription revenue. But I'm thinking both the airport business and the rail security business will be able to move to more subscription base over the next several years. I think you ought to continue to view this though as it's project based, at least in the near term, it's going to be project-based and tend to be a little bit lumpy in terms of overall timing. But I'm pleased some of our investment strategies that we put in place, particularly in the airports area, have started to bear fruit. We've got growth this quarter. I'm expecting that will grow again that segment of the business in the next quarter. So I think we've got some good plans to get the trajectory of that. So it's not offsetting the good growth that we've consistently seen in core aviation. Also remember that it is less profitable than the core aviation component of the business. So I don't think we're going to see significant changes in the overall profitability of that segment. The incremental margin performance really comes out of the core aviation growth.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question is from Myles Walton with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In your investor marketing deck, the range of R&D has gone to 16% to 18% of sales and back at the analysts -- at the Investor Day back in 2014, you rolled out a 18% to 20%. Looks like this year, you'll be above that 16% to 18% range. Next year, I think yo
componenttext: In your investor marketing deck, the range of R&D has gone to 16% to 18% of sales and back at the analysts -- at the Investor Day back in 2014, you rolled out a 18% to 20%. Looks like this year, you'll be above that 16% to 18% range. Next year, I think you might be below that range. Can you talk about why that range moved and kind of what's the sustainable rates at a company level for R&D?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I still think the 16% to 18% is a reasonable long-term range. And I think we are going to be a bit beyond above that range this year. I think you -- I'd characterize a couple of different things. One is the deferred balance is still very high. We'll see t
componenttext: I still think the 16% to 18% is a reasonable long-term range. And I think we are going to be a bit beyond above that range this year. I think you -- I'd characterize a couple of different things. One is the deferred balance is still very high. We'll see that come down. We'll see company funded and customer funded maybe change over time. But I think the big thing that's going to drive that down back into the range of 16% to 18% is the reduction in referred. Now why did the range change? But change for us was adding the sales of IMS. And if you look at the IMS portfolio, we really don't have much in a way of R&D at all. The investments in IMS tend to be capitalized software mostly. So that does there more capital expenditures. So that's, hopefully, that gives you a little bit of color. So I do feel, longer-term comfortable with that 16% to 18% range, and I think it'll come as the deferred winds down.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And Patrick, the amortization pre-production next year, is it still about $30 million headwind that I would say in the Q when it comes out?
componenttext: Got it. And Patrick, the amortization pre-production next year, is it still about $30 million headwind that I would say in the Q when it comes out?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's about right, yes. It hasn't changed much.
componenttext: I think that's about right, yes. It hasn't changed much.

componenttext: The next question is from Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.

componenttext: Okay. The reason I'm asking is that contract -- im, the commercial side of company funded R&D year-to-date is down 30%. So I guess it depends where the fourth quarter shakes out. But that contract would play a pretty significant increase in the commercial side in '17 versus your comment earlier that would tick up.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, yes, I would expect an increase. Now again, no one, I want to make it clear. We're still in the teeth of our internal operating plan cycle, and that involves a lot of discussions around investment and a lot of trade-offs. And those have not b
componenttext: I would say, yes, I would expect an increase. Now again, no one, I want to make it clear. We're still in the teeth of our internal operating plan cycle, and that involves a lot of discussions around investment and a lot of trade-offs. And those have not been completed yet. But do I expect an increase in funded? I absolutely do. I would hesitate to quantify it right now just because we're so early in the planning process.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And fundamentally, no, I think you got to remember that we did not defer the development of the 777X. We're spending that. So we're just in preliminary design phase here mid this year, and now will ramp-up. Next year will be a peak spending year for
componenttext: Yes. And fundamentally, no, I think you got to remember that we did not defer the development of the 777X. We're spending that. So we're just in preliminary design phase here mid this year, and now will ramp-up. Next year will be a peak spending year for us in 777. So if we aren't deferring these, and we expensing see, you will see all bit more quarter-to-quarter dynamics as we're managing through the development of the programs.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that helps clarify. And then one other follow-up on the Boeing delinquency, how abnormal versus history is that? And what levers do you have to pull it to get paid?
componenttext: Okay, that helps clarify. And then one other follow-up on the Boeing delinquency, how abnormal versus history is that? And what levers do you have to pull it to get paid?

componenttextpreview: That's abnormal to history that's normally been paid good. I hope it's just a blip. Our avenues are to work our strong relationship with them and get that resolved, and we're in the process of doing that.
componenttext: That's abnormal to history that's normally been paid good. I hope it's just a blip. Our avenues are to work our strong relationship with them and get that resolved, and we're in the process of doing that.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from David Strauss with UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from David Strauss with UBS.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, can you talk about the ability for you to do some additional restructuring to offset what looks like a more challenging than expected bizjet OE side? And then, Patrick, one follow-up. Based on the change in guidance, was there any adjustment to you
componenttext: Kelly, can you talk about the ability for you to do some additional restructuring to offset what looks like a more challenging than expected bizjet OE side? And then, Patrick, one follow-up. Based on the change in guidance, was there any adjustment to your comp of growth for the year?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as far as restructuring, we're always looking to size the business to the end market demand. So if the end market is less, then there's all sorts of things that we can do to either shift our resources to where we've got growth or to consolidate acti
componenttext: Well, as far as restructuring, we're always looking to size the business to the end market demand. So if the end market is less, then there's all sorts of things that we can do to either shift our resources to where we've got growth or to consolidate activities. And that's part of our planning process as we are in the middle of that right now. I think particularly around the manufacturing, if we're not going to be delivering as much in Business Aviation, we're going to have to really take a hard look at our overall cost structure around that, especially if we don't see signs that this is temporary. If this is a long-term phenomenon, which right now, it looks like, I think we've got to make sure we've got the overall cost base pretty well sized. I think you can look from historically, we're pretty aggressive in that regard. We'll take all the action we need to to make sure we stay lean and mean in spite of a challenging market conditions.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as it relates of the comp of growth, the biggest dynamic over the course of the year has been cash flow. If you remember, we raised it $50 million when we got the R&D tax credit. Now we lower it at 50. So it went up a little bit over 100%. Now it's do
componenttext: And as it relates of the comp of growth, the biggest dynamic over the course of the year has been cash flow. If you remember, we raised it $50 million when we got the R&D tax credit. Now we lower it at 50. So it went up a little bit over 100%. Now it's down closer to right around 100% for the year. Now as we look at quarter-over-quarter, it was not a big driver. I think it may have been $1 million or $2 million.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Rockwell Collins Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.For opening remarks and management introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Rockwell Collins' Vice Pres
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Rockwell Collins Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded.
For opening remarks and management introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Rockwell Collins' Vice President of Investor Relations, Ryan Miller. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and good morning to all of you on the call. With me on the line this morning are Rockwell Collins' Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Kelly Ortberg; and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Patrick Allen.Tod
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and good morning to all of you on the call. With me on the line this morning are Rockwell Collins' Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, Kelly Ortberg; and Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Patrick Allen.
Today's call is being webcast, and you can view the slides we'll be presenting today on our website at www.rockwellcollins.com under the Investor Relations tab. These slides include certain non-GAAP financial information and a reconciliation to the related GAAP measure.
Please note, today's presentation and webcast will include certain projections and statements that are forward looking. Actual results may differ materially from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including those detailed on Slide 2 of this webcast presentation and from time to time in the company's Securities and Exchange Commission filings. These forward-looking statements are made as of today, and the company assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements.
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Kelly.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Ryan, and good morning, everyone. This was really a solid quarter for us as we saw some major accomplishments in our markets and also had good execution performance in all of our businesses.Among the market highlights was the CSeries entry
componenttext:
Well, thanks, Ryan, and good morning, everyone. This was really a solid quarter for us as we saw some major accomplishments in our markets and also had good execution performance in all of our businesses.
Among the market highlights was the CSeries entry into service with Swiss Air. We're very pleased to see Bombardier accomplish this major milestone, and it's a real sign that this program is turning the quarter. As you know, this has been a big investment for us, and we're all pleased to be moving from the investment phase to the return phase for this program.
Another major OEM accomplishment was the successful refueling test with the KC-46 tanker, paving the way towards production of that airplane. These are both important programs for our long-term growth in our commercial and government businesses. Annually, both Boeing and Airbus survey the airlines to gauge their supplier performance and customer support. And recently, it was announced that Rockwell Collins was ranked #1 for both Airbus and Boeing. In fact, we're ranked ahead both of the OEMs themselves. I'm very proud of our team's performance, which is a testament to our brand promise of building trust every day, and it will help us to continue to be the supplier of choice in our markets.
Overall, we executed our business quite well during the quarter, delivering solid margin performance, while also stepping up our R&D spending in Commercial Systems to support the development of the 777X. We also made great progress in booking the government orders necessary to achieve our abnormally large second-half sales plan. And our IMS business grew 10%, and we achieved our expected growth in the non-aviation segment, which demonstrates that some of our strategies to grow that portion of the business are beginning to take traction.
Now we're not without challenges, and they seem to be focused in our Commercial Systems markets right now. The Business Aviation and market continues to struggle to find the bottom. This last quarter, we saw shaky utilization, and recently, we've seen even further declines in demand from the OEMs. If you recall, we started the year with some discount in OEM production, and we saw reduced demand at the beginning of the calendar year, which used up our discount and then some. I was hoping to see demand stabilize through the summer, but unfortunately, this hasn't been the case. This is going to further impact our top line in Commercial Systems. Just to give you some color on this. It's not really specific to any particular airplane type, but rather an overall market condition.
We're seeing softness in product demand across all major business jet manufacturers. Recall that we moved our fiscal 2016 guidance back to the fourth quarter earnings call to allow us to get better aligned with the OEMs, and I think this is going to be really applicable to the bizjet demand this year. It's not yet clear to us how these latest changes from the OEMs will impact their 2017 demand. And I'm sure that they're going to be monitoring the next quarter of market dynamics before they set that outlook.
In addition, we've had another quarter of no growth in air transport MRO. And in the last earnings call, I indicated that I believe this is a structural change to our aftermarket due to the component recycling practices at the airlines. So if you couple the Business Aviation OEM and the air transport aftermarket sales environments, we're lowering our Commercial Systems sales forecast for the year from up single-digits to down about 1%.
On a more positive note, as I mentioned earlier, Government Systems had a nice quarter in sales and earnings, but has an even bigger fourth quarter yet to go. And as I've done in the last couple calls, I'd like to give you some granularity on how we're progressing in capturing the business to achieve that growth.
During the last quarterly call, I said that 77% of the second half growth was either in backlog or coming from annual follow-on buys. This is now at 94% at the end of the third quarter. So I remain very confident in our ability to achieve the sales growth that we projected and finished the year strong.
Some of these sales will be later in the year than we originally planned, and it's going to stress our ability to collect cash by year-end, and that's a contributor to us adjusting our guidance on cash flow to lower end of our previous range. 
So to summarize before Patrick takes you through the details of the quarter, we really executed well this past quarter. I'm particularly pleased to see the restructuring savings flowing as we expected, and we are successfully bringing in the government business needed to accomplish the abnormally large second half ramp. Business Aviation remains a challenge for us as the industry is still searching for the bottom of the market. And I continue to see good things from our IMS business, and we're making good progress on the new OEM programs that will set us up for future growth.
So with that, let me turn the call over to Patrick to walk us through the quarterly details.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kelly, and morning to everyone as well. I'd now like to walk you through today's presentation slide that summarize our results for the third quarter of fiscal year 2016. I'll begin on Slide 3, where we highlight our total company third quarter sal
componenttext:
Thanks, Kelly, and morning to everyone as well. I'd now like to walk you through today's presentation slide that summarize our results for the third quarter of fiscal year 2016. I'll begin on Slide 3, where we highlight our total company third quarter sales, earnings per share, income from continuing operations and shares outstanding.
Total company sales for the quarter increased $41 million or 3% compared to the third quarter of last year, primarily due to higher Government Systems and Information Management Services sales. Income from continuing operations increased $36 million or 20%, and earnings per share from continuing operations increased $0.30 or 23% compared to the same period last year. The increase in income and earnings per share from continuing operations was primarily due to lower income tax expense that was favorably impacted by the release of the valuation allowance related to a capital loss carryforward as well as higher pretax earnings from the higher sales.
As we turn to Slide 4. Commercial Systems achieved revenue of $612 million in the quarter, about flat with the same period last year. Sales related to aircraft OEMs decreased $6 million or 2% to $367 million, primarily due to lower business jet aircraft OEM production rates, lower product deliveries to a Chinese regional jet manufacturer and lower Airbus A330 production rates. This was mostly offset by higher deliveries that supported the A350 and 787 production rate ramps, favorable customer timing for airline selectable equipment, higher Bombardier CSeries sales in support of its entry into service this year and higher customer-funded development program revenues. Aftermarket sales increased $11 million or 5% due to higher simulation hardware deliveries, inorganic sales from the acquisition of International Communications Group and higher flight deck retrofits, partially offset by lower spares provisioning and lower cabin retrofits.
On Commercial Systems, operating earnings were flat at $141 million, and operating earnings (sic) [ margins ] were about flat at 23%. Operating earnings and margins were flat with the prior year as benefits from the cost savings initiatives from previously announced restructuring plans were offset by unfavorable sales mix as lower margin customer-funded development sales increased and higher-margin business jet OEM sales decreased.
Moving on to Slide 5. Government Systems overall revenue increased by 5% to $555 million, driven by higher fixed-wing platform revenues and higher simulation training sales, partially offset by lower deliveries of various rotary wind platforms, the wind-down of an international electronic warfare program and lower international deliveries of targeting systems.
Government Systems third quarter operating earnings increased $7 million to $115 million, resulting in an operating margin of 20.7%, a 30 basis point improvement compared to the third quarter of the prior year. The increased operating earnings resulted from the higher sales volume and cost saving initiatives from previously announced restructuring plans, partially offset by unfavorable development program adjustments.
Turning to Slide 6. Information Management Services' sales increased 10% over the prior year as commercial and Business Aviation services' sales increased 9%, while the non-aviation-related businesses increased 11%, primarily due to higher airport and rail program sales. Information Management Services' third quarter operating earnings increased $3 million to $26 million, resulting in an operating margin of 15.6% compared to 15.1% in the third quarter of last year. The increase in operating earnings and margin was due to the incremental earnings from higher sales volume.
Looking next to Slide 7. We show our year-to-date results for revenue, income from continuing operations, earnings per share and operating cash flow. Through the third quarter, we generated $223 million of operating cash flow compared to $341 million last year. The decrease in cash generation resulted primarily from the timing of sales and lower advance payments from our customers. These items were partially offset by lower tax payments.
Slide 8 provides an update to our total R&D investment. Total spend decreased from $731 million in the first 9 months of fiscal 2015 to $741 million year-to-date in fiscal 2016. Company funded R&D decreased $47 million due to lower business jet development cost in Commercial Systems and lower software-defined radio development costs in Government Systems. Customer funded research and development expense increased $25 million due to higher development costs for international regional jet development programs in Commercial Systems, partially offset by the wind-down of an international electronic warfare program in Government Systems. Preproduction engineering investment net increased due to higher costs incurred for certain military transport programs in Government Systems and the Global 7000/8000 program, partially offset by lower spend on the CSeries program.
Moving to Slide 9. We show the status of our capital structure as of the end of the third quarter compared to the end of last year. During the first 9 months of fiscal 2016, our debt-to-EBITDA ratio increased to 2 from 1.7 at year-end. The increase was primarily due to an increase in commercial paper as the first 3 quarters of the year had typically light cash flows. I expect the level of debt to come down over the balance of the year as a larger portion of our cash flow is traditionally generated later in the year and we pay down a portion of that short-term debt.
The updated status of the share repurchase program as of the end of the quarter is detailed on Slide 10. During the third quarter, we repurchased 0.7 million shares at an average cost of $90.71. Our repurchase authority remaining at the end of the quarter was $125 million.
Now to move to Slide 11, where we provide a summary of our fiscal 2016 financial guidance, which has been updated as we enter the last fiscal quarter of the year. Total sales are now expected to be about $5.3 billion, which is the bottom of the previously guided range of $5.3 billion to $5.4 billion. As Kelly discussed in his opening remarks, we have updated Commercial Systems sales to be down about percentage point this year due to softness in business jet OEM deliveries as well as muted market conditions in air transport service and support. We have narrowed the earnings per share guidance to $5.50 to $5.55, which is within the previously guided range of $5.45 to $5.65.
We have also updated our cash flow from operations outlook to be about $750 million, which is the bottom of the previously guided range, due primarily to the timing of receivable collections and higher preproduction engineering spend. Our guidance for total segment operating margins, research and development investment and capital expenditures is unchanged from the previous guidance.
With that, that's the end of my review of the financial results and projection. So Ryan, back to you to kick off the Q&A session.

componenttext: Well, let me answer the last part first. Dassault, we primarily do cabin equipment for Dassault, so it's not a -- those aren't superheavy content aircraft for us, but we are exposed to that. We're seeing it really across all categories of aircraft. As I said in the comments, it really -- I can't point right now to -- this is a heavy phenomenon or a median or a light phenomenon. It's really across the board. I think everybody has gotten through another quarter. It's not been an overly good quarter in terms of the end markets, and I think everybody is truing up their outlook for the balance of the year. As I mentioned, I had hoped that we get through the summer, but we were clear to point out that the summer time [indiscernible] adjusted rates, we're probably going to hear about it. And unfortunately, we have been hearing about it from all of them.

componenttext: Well, it's a good question, Sam. But I think there may be a little bit of opportunity in our CapEx number. Do you think that the sort of summer season for weakness is one of these moves that's kind of sufficient to get rightsized? headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Carter, I can't see any conditions at this point that say, "hey, that's it, we're at the bottom." The market continues to struggle. What I said in my opening remarks was it's not clear to us yet how these adjustments that we just recently received a
componenttext: Well, Carter, I can't see any conditions at this point that say, "hey, that's it, we're at the bottom." The market continues to struggle. What I said in my opening remarks was it's not clear to us yet how these adjustments that we just recently received are going to impact their long-term or, particularly, their '17 production rates. My assumption sitting here today would be if we don't see some sort of a market improvement, that these adjustments are going to set the go-in production rates going into next year. Hopefully, that'll at least give us a stable base going forward, unless the market conditions continue to erode.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
