componenttext: So is it safe to say that you're planning accordingly given that lack of visibility to have the flexibility in case it needs to be lower as well?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're -- as Pat said, we're in the middle of putting together our '17 plan right now. I think we're going to be pretty conservative in our outlook, which I thought we were coming into this fiscal year. We put the discount there, and it turned out eve
componenttext: Yes. We're -- as Pat said, we're in the middle of putting together our '17 plan right now. I think we're going to be pretty conservative in our outlook, which I thought we were coming into this fiscal year. We put the discount there, and it turned out even that was too even optimistic. So yes, we're all looking for the bottom. I think when you're looking for the bottom, you're going to tend to plan pretty conservatively and hope for upside.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Gursky with Citi.
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Gursky with Citi.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, I was wondering if you could just spend a few minutes and talk a little bit about your mid- to longer-term revenue and earnings goals in the context of all the puts and takes that you're seeing. Maybe highlight for us your thoughts here on this cal
componenttext: Kelly, I was wondering if you could just spend a few minutes and talk a little bit about your mid- to longer-term revenue and earnings goals in the context of all the puts and takes that you're seeing. Maybe highlight for us your thoughts here on this call about some of the downside risks. But maybe provide a little bit of an update on the key drivers for growth that may allow us to get to that mid to long-term growth targets that you've got for both revenue and earnings.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think, first of all, the linearity of that long-term outlook certainly hasn't been what we expected. And there have been puts and takes, both positive and negative. I think we're, in the short term, dealing with a lot of the negative, which is del
componenttext: Sure. I think, first of all, the linearity of that long-term outlook certainly hasn't been what we expected. And there have been puts and takes, both positive and negative. I think we're, in the short term, dealing with a lot of the negative, which is delays in entry into service programs, lower aftermarket MRO component than we originally expected and a much, much weaker business aviation demand than we anticipated. On the positive side, we gained additional share on the 777X. We've seen increases in production rates in narrow-body aircraft, significant increases in production rates on narrow-body aircraft. Of course, we've got the new -- a lot of new positions with the MAX and the 777X are petting in. That's not necessarily new, but continue to be growth drivers for us. And then we planned our defense business at that time at a sequester level, and currently, the budget environment is clearly better than that. So our ability to grow from -- for our government business is certainly a little bit better. I think the -- as I look at that outlook and how we're doing against it, obviously, '16, we're not achieving the top level numbers. '17, I think we're going to have to take a hard look at Business Aviation. It's the wildcard for us. If we can just get that business to stabilize, I think we can grow the company. If you put in perspective, Business Aviation OEM is about 20% to 25% of our commercial revenues are about 10% of that company revenues. And so when we can get to flat, we can grow the company. The challenge is quarters like this one, where we've got 22% decline in Business Aviation, is offsetting a lot of really good growth for us. And the information management business, I think, continues to track pretty well to our original plan.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: The next question is from Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a 2-part question on business jets. First, all of the manufacturers reporting have cited pricing has been particularly weak because of the erosion in the preowned market. Are you seeing any negative pricing pressures? And secondly, usually, when OE
componenttext: I have a 2-part question on business jets. First, all of the manufacturers reporting have cited pricing has been particularly weak because of the erosion in the preowned market. Are you seeing any negative pricing pressures? And secondly, usually, when OE is off and prices of preowns come down, you start to see a pickup in preowned sales that tends to bolster the aftermarket. Are you seeing any positive signs or potential positive signs in bizjet aftermarket?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the bizjet aftermarket has been pretty good for us for the whole year. We continue to see good retrofit activity in avionics, which I do view as a positive sign. Last year, it was probably more focused on cabin upgrade, that nobody was upgrading the
componenttext: Well, the bizjet aftermarket has been pretty good for us for the whole year. We continue to see good retrofit activity in avionics, which I do view as a positive sign. Last year, it was probably more focused on cabin upgrade, that nobody was upgrading the front end of the airplane. But now we're seeing that, and that's continued through this quarter. Regarding pricing pressure, I think our near-term pricing is pretty fixed relative to the market. So I think the OEMs have to deal with that. They're certainly turning around and looking to the supply chain to help them in any way, but that's not unique to the business aviation market.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Seth Seifman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Seth Seifman with JPMorgan.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could talk a little bit more about -- in the air transport aftermarket, what happened at Intertrade in the quarter? And also what the contribution was from the acquisitions that you did in 2015? Just to get a sense of kind of where the org
componenttext: I wonder if you could talk a little bit more about -- in the air transport aftermarket, what happened at Intertrade in the quarter? And also what the contribution was from the acquisitions that you did in 2015? Just to get a sense of kind of where the organic business is. It seems you faced some pressure here before, and we talked about some of the causes, but it seems to be gathering some strength. And just kind of wondering if you have any insight into why that's the case.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you look at the -- if you peel the onion way back, I'd say, in air transport, our MRO, just core MRO, not used components, was down low single digit, and that was offset by some Intertrade growth for the quarter. As far as the inorganic growth, it
componenttext: Yes. If you look at the -- if you peel the onion way back, I'd say, in air transport, our MRO, just core MRO, not used components, was down low single digit, and that was offset by some Intertrade growth for the quarter. As far as the inorganic growth, it's primarily coming out of our ICG acquisition, which is the satellite-based communications equipment. I think about $4 million of ICG growth was in the air transport and another couple million was in bizav.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And just -- do you get a sense that the pressure -- the structural pressure that you've talked about in the commercial air transport aftermarket has been gathering steam? Just because it seems like retirements have been moderating and traffic
componenttext: Okay. Great. And just -- do you get a sense that the pressure -- the structural pressure that you've talked about in the commercial air transport aftermarket has been gathering steam? Just because it seems like retirements have been moderating and traffic growth has been fairly solid, but it does seem like these headwinds have been increasing.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think they have, for -- certainly, for our portfolio. If you look at our installed base, it's heavily leveraged on 75, 76 and 747-400. And while we have seen retirements abate a bit, it's been more in the narrow bodies, which is not as significant
componenttext: Yes. I think they have, for -- certainly, for our portfolio. If you look at our installed base, it's heavily leveraged on 75, 76 and 747-400. And while we have seen retirements abate a bit, it's been more in the narrow bodies, which is not as significant of an installed base today for us because we don't have flight decks in the narrow bodies. So our portfolio is feeling probably a little bit more the impact of recycling. And that's coming in 2 ways. We don't get the repair action through our service center. But also, we're seeing lower, what I'll call, legacy spares, where someone is just buying our legacy product because they're able to fill that spare with the used component.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from George Shapiro with Shapiro research.
componenttext: The next question is from George Shapiro with Shapiro research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, I just wanted to pursue a little bit more of the business jet market because while Bombardier and Embraer deliveries are down, Cessna actually had quite a decent increase in air deliveries in the second quarter. So it's some of your comments relate
componenttext: Kelly, I just wanted to pursue a little bit more of the business jet market because while Bombardier and Embraer deliveries are down, Cessna actually had quite a decent increase in air deliveries in the second quarter. So it's some of your comments related to the fact that on the newer Cessna products, you don't have the market share that you used to have.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, at Cessna, you do you have to go look at the mix. I think we have a mix. I think they were -- the King Air deliveries were reported down quite a bit, and of course, we have the King Air position, so -- and we don't on some of the new growth
componenttext: Yes. I think, at Cessna, you do you have to go look at the mix. I think we have a mix. I think they were -- the King Air deliveries were reported down quite a bit, and of course, we have the King Air position, so -- and we don't on some of the new growth platforms down there. So I do think that's a little bit of a mix issue at Cessna.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Robert Spingarn with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question comes from Robert Spingarn with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question and clarification. Patrick, on the clarification on the cash flows, is there any component of that, that is on the commercial side, maybe in terms of receivables from some of your OEM customers in terms of timing on their payables? And th
componenttext: I had a question and clarification. Patrick, on the clarification on the cash flows, is there any component of that, that is on the commercial side, maybe in terms of receivables from some of your OEM customers in terms of timing on their payables? And then, Kelly, on the cabin retrofit and some of the weakness there, could you speak -- talk to that a little bit? Where are you seeing that and what's the dynamic behind that?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me answer the first part of your question, Rob. I think it's fair to say that we always have puts and takes with respect to cash flow timing, particularly at year-end because a day or 2 can mean quite a bit in terms of our cash flow. So that's always
componenttext: Let me answer the first part of your question, Rob. I think it's fair to say that we always have puts and takes with respect to cash flow timing, particularly at year-end because a day or 2 can mean quite a bit in terms of our cash flow. So that's always a risk and an opportunity. I wouldn't say that we have anything specifically baked in with respect to commercial OEM, I'll say paying behavior. So anyhow, we'll continue to monitor it. But no, there's nothing specific to commercial payment practices.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Patrick, no one has made an effort to change payable terms?
componenttext: Patrick, no one has made an effort to change payable terms?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I didn't say that. I think we have a -- a couple of our larger customers have been -- are very active in terms of talking to us about cash flow payment terms, and we're continuing to negotiate that. But I would tell you that we're still working it.
componenttext: I didn't say that. I think we have a -- a couple of our larger customers have been -- are very active in terms of talking to us about cash flow payment terms, and we're continuing to negotiate that. But I would tell you that we're still working it.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, Boeing -- we do not have a Boeing replan in terms of their payment strategy in our full year outlook. That's not in accordance with our contracts that we have with them. So we're expecting them to withhold that. I will say quarter to date, Boeing is
componenttext: Look, Boeing -- we do not have a Boeing replan in terms of their payment strategy in our full year outlook. That's not in accordance with our contracts that we have with them. So we're expecting them to withhold that. I will say quarter to date, Boeing is delinquent and Boeing has contributed to some of our underperformance here this quarter in cash flow, which is disappointing, but we're working that with them.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on that retrofit?
componenttext: Okay. And then just on that retrofit?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Rob, on the retrofit, I don't know whether I can point to anything market-wise. It truly is we're just seeing, when the airplanes are coming in for engine mods or maintenance actions, that we're selling more avionics and less cabin. It appears to be
componenttext: Yes. Rob, on the retrofit, I don't know whether I can point to anything market-wise. It truly is we're just seeing, when the airplanes are coming in for engine mods or maintenance actions, that we're selling more avionics and less cabin. It appears to be they kind of have a fixed amount of money, and the money shifting a little bit towards the avionics upgrades. I don't know if that's because they think they need those avionics upgrades to sell the airplane. Some of them are mandated kind of things, and they're just saying let's go ahead and do them right now might be indicative of them keeping the aircraft longer. Now, cabin upgrades haven't gone away. They were just particularly strong last quarter, and they're not as strong here through this year.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Howard Rubel with Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from Howard Rubel with Jefferies.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to shift a little bit towards some new products, Kelly. Two things, one is, you highlighted the simulator business and demand. Is there something that's changed permanently, I mean, given the pilot shortage? And then just very briefly touch on, you
componenttext: I want to shift a little bit towards some new products, Kelly. Two things, one is, you highlighted the simulator business and demand. Is there something that's changed permanently, I mean, given the pilot shortage? And then just very briefly touch on, you have 73 max, you have CSeries and A350 all ramping fairly substantially next year. Could you elaborate a little bit on the trajectory?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you look at the ramp-ups next year, you're right on the ramps. If you look at 737 MAX, that's going to feather in over probably about 3-year timeframe as they transition from NG to MAX. At Boeing next year, while I'm not -- I don't have a plan yet
componenttext: Yes. If you look at the ramp-ups next year, you're right on the ramps. If you look at 737 MAX, that's going to feather in over probably about 3-year timeframe as they transition from NG to MAX. At Boeing next year, while I'm not -- I don't have a plan yet that I'm sitting in front of. I would expect that we'll see the MAX tailwind be offset by declines in the 777 and the 747-8. So we'll tend to mute themselves in fiscal '17, but then we'll see the incremental growth in '18 and '19 as we continue to feather in the MAX. I think we're all watching Airbus' ramp-up on A350. Right now, we're pretty well aligned with their public guidance there. But I think everybody is watching to see if they're going to be able to achieve that going forward. So hopefully, we'll get some more clarity before we have to provide any guidance on '17.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as it relates to the simulator products, I would say those products tend to be a little bit lumpy, just in terms of the timing of the deliveries. I wouldn't read it in terms of, I'll say, a permanent change to the trajectory of that business. It's sti
componenttext: And as it relates to the simulator products, I would say those products tend to be a little bit lumpy, just in terms of the timing of the deliveries. I wouldn't read it in terms of, I'll say, a permanent change to the trajectory of that business. It's still remains to be a pretty good business. We still anticipate good growth in that business. But I think, it was a little bit unusual this quarter.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there's no share gain or anything else that you can point to, Patrick?
componenttext: So there's no share gain or anything else that you can point to, Patrick?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think there are probably a fair amount of deliveries across the board. Actually, there are a lot of deliveries in the commercial side of the business for some similar products. I don't think there was a lot of share gain, though.
componenttext: No, I think there are probably a fair amount of deliveries across the board. Actually, there are a lot of deliveries in the commercial side of the business for some similar products. I don't think there was a lot of share gain, though.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ken Herbert with Canaccord.
componenttext: The next question is from Ken Herbert with Canaccord.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to shift gears again to the Government Systems. You had good growth in the quarter, and I know it's consistent with what you've been talking about, and it sounds like the full year outlook remains on track. Can you specifically, 2 parts, speci
componenttext: Just wanted to shift gears again to the Government Systems. You had good growth in the quarter, and I know it's consistent with what you've been talking about, and it sounds like the full year outlook remains on track. Can you specifically, 2 parts, specifically highlight anymore detail on specific programs you saw ramping this quarter or any other color on the specific strength there? And then second, can you provide an update on the Manpack opportunity? I know the radios are getting tested now. And any further detail on when you're looking for the potential down select there? And any update on the testing process?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me hit Manpack. First of all, yes, we've delivered the units as have the competitors, and they're in the test process. I'm probably not going to be providing you much detailed information. It's highly competitive between now and the downselect
componenttext: Yes, so let me hit Manpack. First of all, yes, we've delivered the units as have the competitors, and they're in the test process. I'm probably not going to be providing you much detailed information. It's highly competitive between now and the downselection. So I'm not going to be speaking too much of anymore about what's going on relative to Manpack. We do expect the downselect to be towards the end of the second quarter or early third quarter of next fiscal year. As far as government programs, if you look in the third quarter, we saw some pretty good growth in military simulation and training. Our E-6 program had some good growth and international PIII [ph] also. We saw continued decline year-on-year in rotary wing, primarily driven by the oil and gas challenges that we've been dealing with. If you look towards the fourth quarter, I think you're going to see pretty good growth across our entire government portfolio. And in fact, I think our COM/NAV portfolio will probably exceed our Avionics portfolio in terms of overall growth, where key programs there are, international C-130s, and we've done a good job of booking those. You may have seen a press release where we won a Blackhawk simulator program down in Mexico. That was one of those that we had planned to win and convert in the year. We've got growth in F-35, continued growth in  E-6 and then some simulation and training products that we're expecting to grow. So again, a pretty big fourth quarter, abnormally big fourth quarter for us in our government portfolio. But pretty much the majority of that is booked and now executing. And I expect that we'll have a really bang up quarter here for our government business, which is good. This is the first -- this Q3 was the first quarter of growth in quite a few quarters here for our government business. So it's good to get that finally turning in the right direction.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from David Strauss of UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from David Strauss of UBS.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, want to see if you could touch on this trajectory of company-funded R&D as we head into '17. I think you had -- you spoken previously about '17 looking a lot more like fiscal '15 rather than '16 in terms of company-funded R&D, if you could touch on
componenttext: Kelly, want to see if you could touch on this trajectory of company-funded R&D as we head into '17. I think you had -- you spoken previously about '17 looking a lot more like fiscal '15 rather than '16 in terms of company-funded R&D, if you could touch on that. And then also touch on, assuming that on the company funded side along with the increase in preproduction amortization. It looks like it's going to be tough for Commercial Systems EBIT to grow even if you were to assume that business jet were -- was flat in '17. If you could just touch on that.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the first half of this year has been a low half in terms of Commercial Systems company-funded R&D. And you're seeing us ramp that up here in the third quarter. You'll see additional ramp up in the fourth quarter. So I think, while again, I don't h
componenttext: Yes. So the first half of this year has been a low half in terms of Commercial Systems company-funded R&D. And you're seeing us ramp that up here in the third quarter. You'll see additional ramp up in the fourth quarter. So I think, while again, I don't have '17's detailed plan. I think '17, you can expect us to be spending kind of more at the rate at which we're ramping to right now. Obviously, the more expensed R&D that we spend on the year, the more challenge that places on -- are on our government revenues. I wouldn't say that's necessarily, I'm sorry, a commercial margin. I wouldn't necessarily say that's new. We've always known that we were going to be ramping back up the R&D, and we've got to go drive the good news out of the product profitability in order to offset that R&D ramp.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Michael Ciarmoli with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Michael Ciarmoli with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, maybe if we could just go back to the Government Systems, you were hitting on it. Best quarter of growth, I think, since fiscal '11. Fourth quarter looks to be strong. You've got some easy comps in the first half. I mean, are we out of the woods he
componenttext: Kelly, maybe if we could just go back to the Government Systems, you were hitting on it. Best quarter of growth, I think, since fiscal '11. Fourth quarter looks to be strong. You've got some easy comps in the first half. I mean, are we out of the woods here based on current visibility, what you're seeing in the pipeline programs? I mean, can we expect Government Systems to start putting up consistent year-over-year growth at this point? Or from your perspective, is it too early to call?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you can start to see that we're going to have consistent year-on-year growth coming out of our government portfolio. Now this year is strange because we had the first half, second half. I don't think you should assume that we're going to conti
componenttext: No, I think you can start to see that we're going to have consistent year-on-year growth coming out of our government portfolio. Now this year is strange because we had the first half, second half. I don't think you should assume that we're going to continue to grow at the second half rate. But what we've said was to get flat in '15, low single-digit growth coming out. And I think the budget environment is going to allow us over the next couple of years to move that growth rate to low- to mid-single-digit growth out of our government portfolio, which is upside from our long-term outlook, as I've talked about before.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just, if I may, are there headwinds out there? And I think about maybe the Brazilian economy, the KC-390. Are there specific programs you might be more worried about creating some unforeseen headwinds in government?
componenttext: Got it. And just, if I may, are there headwinds out there? And I think about maybe the Brazilian economy, the KC-390. Are there specific programs you might be more worried about creating some unforeseen headwinds in government?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that KC-390 is going to go through some challenging times going forward. I think that we've got that baked into our overall outlook. I think oil and gas continues to be a question mark for a civil helo. But the areas where we're expecting gr
componenttext: Well, I think that KC-390 is going to go through some challenging times going forward. I think that we've got that baked into our overall outlook. I think oil and gas continues to be a question mark for a civil helo. But the areas where we're expecting growth, I think that's why I highlighted KC-46, really important growth program for us. F-35 appears very solid and that's a good growth program for us. And then back to the comment on the Manpack program, that's an important program that will start driving growth here, probably towards the end of next year and into the following year. So we've got the programs and the opportunities ahead of us to have this business on a continuous growth trajectory.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Richard Safran with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: The next question is from Richard Safran with Buckingham Research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to ask you about mandates. If I missed your comments about this and you made it before, I apologize. I know that MRO activity isn't generally a big revenue driver for you, but I believe it could drive cockpit mandates. So I wanted to get a sen
componenttext: So I wanted to ask you about mandates. If I missed your comments about this and you made it before, I apologize. I know that MRO activity isn't generally a big revenue driver for you, but I believe it could drive cockpit mandates. So I wanted to get a sense from you how things like D checks are trending? Are you seeing more D check schedules if you're expecting more mandate activity in the future? How things are looking there?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, I probably can't comment as I looked at specifically on D checks schedule. The only thing I can say is that we -- for mandates, we do typically, especially for the large fleet operators, they try to get those mandates incorporated into their sch
componenttext: You know, I probably can't comment as I looked at specifically on D checks schedule. The only thing I can say is that we -- for mandates, we do typically, especially for the large fleet operators, they try to get those mandates incorporated into their scheduled maintenance outlook. And we saw that with the TCAS changes here in the past 2 years. We've got the ADS-B mandate mostly ahead of us. We're actually expecting some initial revenues in both their transporting governments, bizjets, out of the ADS-B here in the fourth quarter. So that's just picking up. But again, these are mandated with a particular time. So if they don't get them done during their normal scheduled maintenance, then they effectively have to take the airplanes down to do the mods. And unfortunately, we do see a lot of people wait until the very end and a flurry of activity at the very end before the mandate effectivity date hits.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, I was on mute. I wanted to ask about commercial margins on a pre-R&D basis. I guess -- I think you've cited mix as the key driver of the year-to-date compression. And I guess, you've pointed to that being business jet driven, I guess, also, the cus
componenttext: Sorry, I was on mute. I wanted to ask about commercial margins on a pre-R&D basis. I guess -- I think you've cited mix as the key driver of the year-to-date compression. And I guess, you've pointed to that being business jet driven, I guess, also, the customer-funded development sales. But could you talk about how much different the business jet margins are versus the rest of original equipment and versus aftermarket in the commercial business?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I think what we're trying to describe in terms of the year-over-year headwind on margins due to the mix is the bizjet OE compared to customer-funded NRE. So what we're really getting -- we're staying flat. We're trading some pretty high-margin bi
componenttext: Yes. No, I think what we're trying to describe in terms of the year-over-year headwind on margins due to the mix is the bizjet OE compared to customer-funded NRE. So what we're really getting -- we're staying flat. We're trading some pretty high-margin bizjet OE for low- to no-margin customer-funded engineering. That's the big mix change. Now as it relates to bizjet OE compared to the entire commercial portfolio, I'd tell you it's among the more profitable businesses we have. I think it's probably -- we've always said bizjet margins are higher than air transport margins. Aftermarket tends to be a little bit higher than OE. But I think, the bizjet OE tends to be a pretty good margin product for us.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So business jet OE is higher than aftermarket on average?
componenttext: So business jet OE is higher than aftermarket on average?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I'd say bizjet is probably on par with it.
componenttext: No. I'd say bizjet is probably on par with it.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And what's your suggestion for..
componenttext: Okay. And what's your suggestion for..

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to clarify. The real impact, though, is the fact that we've got low- to no-margin customer-funded NRE to the portfolio.
componenttext: I just want to clarify. The real impact, though, is the fact that we've got low- to no-margin customer-funded NRE to the portfolio.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what's the net mix impact '17 versus '16 pre-R&D?
componenttext: So what's the net mix impact '17 versus '16 pre-R&D?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the net mix impact should actually pre-R&D should be good. Because I think we're going to see customer-funded NRE coming down, and we'll see some product sales coming up. So the pre-R&D impact is going to be good. The issue then is, okay, what happe
componenttext: Well, the net mix impact should actually pre-R&D should be good. Because I think we're going to see customer-funded NRE coming down, and we'll see some product sales coming up. So the pre-R&D impact is going to be good. The issue then is, okay, what happens to the customer funded -- our company-funded R&D, and Kelly has already referred to it. That may tick up. Pre-R&D margin should benefit from mix.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the next question is from George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the next question is from George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up some on the cash flow, Patrick. I mean, receivables year-to-date are up $160 million, net in -- for example, $160 million and customer advances down $100 million. And you mentioned that you're waiting for a Boeing payment. I don
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up some on the cash flow, Patrick. I mean, receivables year-to-date are up $160 million, net in -- for example, $160 million and customer advances down $100 million. And you mentioned that you're waiting for a Boeing payment. I don't know whether you would quantify how much that is and whether that's related to some contract you haven't signed with them yet or what it was. But the bottom line to me when you add all this together, you need like over $500 million cash flow in the fourth quarter to get to the low end of your guidance. And I'm just trying to put some pieces together as to how you might get there.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you've touched on a few of them anyway, George. As it relates to Boeing, we got probably between $30 million and $40 million of receivables that we are awaiting collection on Boeing. And it's not really a contractual issue. It's just they hav
componenttext: Yes, I think you've touched on a few of them anyway, George. As it relates to Boeing, we got probably between $30 million and $40 million of receivables that we are awaiting collection on Boeing. And it's not really a contractual issue. It's just they haven't paid us. So that's out there. We do need to collect that. We have a very large ramp on the Government Systems revenue side. So you said receivables have spiked up, absolutely have. Getting those billed and collected, the ones that exist as of June 30, it's important. And also the ramp into the fourth quarter and getting that ramp accomplished early billed and collected. I think those are the sort of the keys to getting to that cash flow number. We've always had back-end loaded cash flow. But kind of like the Government System sales this year, it's even more back-end loaded than it has been in the past.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right observing. I mean, you always had a strong cash flow Q4, just much stronger this year.
componenttext: That's right observing. I mean, you always had a strong cash flow Q4, just much stronger this year.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, and I think you've touched on a number of the key drivers to getting that cash flow in the fourth quarter.
componenttext: Yes. Yes, and I think you've touched on a number of the key drivers to getting that cash flow in the fourth quarter.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Peter Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: The next question is from Peter Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, I had a question on commercial rotorcraft. Can you size that unit for us and maybe give us some color on, I'm just guessing is probably down double digits this year and government's just given the market. And I'm wondering if you're seeing that bei
componenttext: Kelly, I had a question on commercial rotorcraft. Can you size that unit for us and maybe give us some color on, I'm just guessing is probably down double digits this year and government's just given the market. And I'm wondering if you're seeing that being another headwind into '17.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so -- again, the commercial rotorcraft is booked in our government portfolio, and it's not all of the commercial rotorcraft that we're seeing being impaired right now. It's the aircraft that are supporting the oil and gas component to the market. Pa
componenttext: Well, so -- again, the commercial rotorcraft is booked in our government portfolio, and it's not all of the commercial rotorcraft that we're seeing being impaired right now. It's the aircraft that are supporting the oil and gas component to the market. Pat, do you have?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We -- it typically says about 15% of our portfolio in Government Systems is helicopters. About 1/3 of that is commercial helicopters. And as Kelly mentioned, some of that civil kind of paramilitary helos, some of it is oil and gas, probably about hal
componenttext: Yes. We -- it typically says about 15% of our portfolio in Government Systems is helicopters. About 1/3 of that is commercial helicopters. And as Kelly mentioned, some of that civil kind of paramilitary helos, some of it is oil and gas, probably about half and a half maybe. So I think this gives you a size as to what the impact would be oil and gas piece is.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one last follow-up. On your strategy to be more service-oriented in terms of the non-aviation businesses, the IMS. Can you give us some color there, maybe in terms how far along you are with that and how much traction you can get there, do you th
componenttext: And just one last follow-up. On your strategy to be more service-oriented in terms of the non-aviation businesses, the IMS. Can you give us some color there, maybe in terms how far along you are with that and how much traction you can get there, do you think?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Probably, the first area that we're making progress in that is in the rail business, where we're providing positive train control, software as a service. We've got that now into the market and we're starting to transition. This isn't going to be a sw
componenttext: Yes. Probably, the first area that we're making progress in that is in the rail business, where we're providing positive train control, software as a service. We've got that now into the market and we're starting to transition. This isn't going to be a switch to where one day, we just flip over and then we move from project to do a subscription revenue. But I think in both the airport business and the rail security business, we'll be able to move to more subscription base over the next several years. I think you ought to continue to view this though as it's project based, at least in the near term, it's going to be project-based and tend to be a little bit more lumpy in terms of overall timing. But I'm pleased some of our investment strategies that we put in place, particularly in the airports area, have started to bear fruit. We've got growth this quarter, I'm expecting that will grow again that segment of the business in the next quarter. So I think we've got some good plans to get the trajectory of that. So it is not offsetting the good growth that we've consistently seen in the core aviation. Also remember that it is less profitable than the core aviation component to the business. So I don't think we're going to see significant changes in the overall profitability of that segment. The incremental margin performance really comes out of the core aviation growth.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: In your investor marketing deck, the range of R&D has gone to 16% to 18% of sales and back at the analyst -- at the Investor Day back in 2014, you rolled out a 18% to 20%. Looks like this year, you'll be above that 16% to 18% range. Next year, I think you
componenttext: In your investor marketing deck, the range of R&D has gone to 16% to 18% of sales and back at the analyst -- at the Investor Day back in 2014, you rolled out a 18% to 20%. Looks like this year, you'll be above that 16% to 18% range. Next year, I think you might be below that range. Can you talk about why that range moved and kind of what's the sustainable rates at a company level for R&D?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I still think the 16% to 18% is a reasonable long-term range. And I think we are going to be a little bit above that range this year. I think you'd -- I'd characterize a couple of different things. One is the deferred balance is still very high, we'll see
componenttext: I still think the 16% to 18% is a reasonable long-term range. And I think we are going to be a little bit above that range this year. I think you'd -- I'd characterize a couple of different things. One is the deferred balance is still very high, we'll see that come down. We'll see company funded and customer funded maybe change over time. But I think the big thing that's going to drive that down back into the range of 16% to 18% is the reduction referred. Now why did the range change? Big change for us was adding the sales of IMS. And if you look at the IMS portfolio, we really don't have much in the way of R&D at all. The investments in IMS tend to be capitalized software mostly. So that does their more capital expenditures. So that's, hopefully, that gives you a little bit of color. So I do feel, longer term comfortable with that 16% to 18% range, and I think it'll come as the deferred winds down.

componenttext: I would say, yes. I would expect an increase. Now again, Noah, I want to make it clear, we're still in the teeth of our operating plan cycle, and that involves a lot of discussions around investments and a lot of trade-offs. And those have not been completed yet. But do I expect an increase in company funded? I absolutely do. I would hesitate to quantify it right now just because we're so early in the planning process.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And fundamentally, Noah, I think you got to remember that we did not defer the development of the 777X. We're spending that. So we're just in preliminary design phase here mid this year, and now we'll ramp up. Next year will be a peak spending year f
componenttext: Yes. And fundamentally, Noah, I think you got to remember that we did not defer the development of the 777X. We're spending that. So we're just in preliminary design phase here mid this year, and now we'll ramp up. Next year will be a peak spending year for us in 777. So if we aren't deferring these, and we're expensing these, you will see all bit more of quarter-to-quarter dynamics as we're managing through the development of the programs.

componenttext: Kelly, can you talk about the ability for you to do some additional restructuring to offset what looks like a more challenging than expected bizjet OE side? And then, Patrick, one follow-up. Based on the change in guidance, was there any adjustment to your comp or growth for the year?

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as far as restructuring, we're always looking to size the business to the end market demand. So if the end market is less, then there's all sorts of things that we can do to either shift resources to where we've got growth or to consolidate activiti
componenttext: Well, as far as restructuring, we're always looking to size the business to the end market demand. So if the end market is less, then there's all sorts of things that we can do to either shift resources to where we've got growth or to consolidate activities. And that's part of our planning process as we're in the middle of that right now. I think, particularly around the manufacturing, if we're not going to be delivering as much in Business Aviation, we're going to have to really take a hard look at our overall cost structure around that, especially if we don't see signs that this is temporary. If this is a long-term phenomenon, which right now, it looks like, I think we've got to make sure we've got the overall cost base pretty well sized. I think you can look from historically, we're pretty aggressive in that regard. We'll take all the action we need to make sure we stay lean and mean, in spite of challenging market conditions.

headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as it relates to the comp or growth, the biggest dynamic over the course of the year has been cash flow. If you remember, we raised it $50 million when we got the R&D tax credit, now we're lowering it $50 million. So it went up to a little bit over 10
componenttext: And as it relates to the comp or growth, the biggest dynamic over the course of the year has been cash flow. If you remember, we raised it $50 million when we got the R&D tax credit, now we're lowering it $50 million. So it went up to a little bit over 100%. Now it's down closer to right around 100% for the year. Now as we look at quarter-over-quarter, it was not a big driver. I think it may have been $1 million or $2 million.

componenttext: Just a final follow-up on, I think, Kelly, you mentioned initial provisioning on commercial transports maybe a bit of a headwind. Specifically, are your A350 provisioning, in general, is it running below plan? And if so, is that due to just the slowness in deliveries from Airbus on that program? headline: Rockwell Collins Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 25, 2016

componenttext: No, we are seeing pretty well our planned initial provisioning at Airbus. And I don't see any delays in the initial provisioning associated with the current ramp-up challenges. Most of the provisioning that we have there -- well, it's not as large as 787 provisioning because we don't have the flight deck. And I think we've been pretty transparent. Also, a lot of the initial aircraft are going to fewer numbers of airlines, which is driving the provisioning plan. But I would say we're pretty well tracking on 350 to what we originally expected.
